Butterfree.comments:
Other Options

Tinted Lens makes Butterfree very threatening but also much less reliable. If running Tinted Lens, Bug Buzz is far better than Hurricane, as Hurricane is likely to miss without Compound Eyes. Giga Drain provides Butterfree with recovery and lets it hit Rock-types, but it doesn't deal much damage and is less useful than Hurricane and Bug Buzz.

Checks and Counters

Priority: Butterfree's low Defense stat makes it very vulnerable to being heavily damaged by incoming priority moves like Shiftry's Sucker Punch and Kangaskhan's Fake Out.

Steel- and Rock-types: Steel-types like Klinklang, Alolan Sandslash, and Galarian Stunfisk and Rock-types such as Rhydon and Kabutops wall Butterfree's Hurricane and OHKO it. However, they struggle against Leftovers sets setting up multiple times with the combination of Substitute + Sleep Powder and being put to sleep in general.

Electric-types: Choice Scarf Electric-types like Rotom formes easily revenge kill Butterfree at +1, putting an end to its sweeping attempt. Bulkier Electric-types like Rotom-S can take care of Butterfree in a pinch, easily living a boosted hit.

Choice Scarf Users: Choice Scarf users like Sawk, Rotom, and Silvally exploit Butterfree's mediocre Speed and revenge kill it.

sets.name: Quiver Dance
sets.description:
Compound Eyes Butterfree's accurate Sleep Powder complements Quiver Dance, making it quite the offensive threat. Although its average Speed and mediocre Special Attack makes Frosmoth seem like a better option in comparison, Butterfree does have a few tricks up its sleeve. Compound Eyes makes Sleep Powder and Hurricane far more threatening with very low chances of missing. Substitute takes advantage of Sleep Powder to provide Butterfree with an extra layer of protection, allowing it to safely use Quiver Dance multiple times. While its 4x weakness to Stealth Rock makes Heavy-Duty Boots seem better, Leftovers makes Butterfree much more consistent if your team has reliable entry hazard removal and prevention.

Butterfree is most effective late-game when a lot of the opposing team is weakened, and it can come in and set up with Quiver Dance to win. However, it is also tremendously threatening in the early-game, especially with Leftovers before Stealth Rock is up. It can set up on and beat common leads such as Rhydon and Galarian Stunfisk and open the way for teammates such as Rotom and Frosmoth. Using Butterfree early-game lets it cripple walls with Sleep Powder. Slow wallbreakers like Flapple, Arctovish, and Alcremie appreciate Butterfree's Sleep Powder, allowing them to safely switch in. In return, Butterfree appreciates their damage making it much easier to KO bulky Pokemon such as Clefairy, Wishiwashi, and Miltank. Butterfree is very frail, and it struggles with Choice Scarf users such as Rotom, Silvally, and Sawk without a Substitute set up. It appreciates bulky teammates like Tangela, Gurdurr, and Uxie, which can come in on opposing attacks, primarily priority attacks that Butterfree is very weak to. When using Leftovers, entry hazard removers like Altaria, Coalossal, and Articuno are needed in order to make sure Butterfree can get onto the field. Entry hazards set by Pokemon like Rhydon, Qwilfish, and Miltank wear down opposing Pokemon for Butterfree, making it easier to sweep.

Clefairy.comments:
Other Options

Aromatherapy allows Clefairy to function as a cleric. Encore can be used to lock opposing setup sweepers such as Frosmoth and Ninetales into an unfavorable move, but Clefairy generally has trouble fitting the move. Thunder Wave is an alternative to Toxic that cripple Poison- and Steel-types like Qwilfish and Perrserker. Teleport allows Clefairy to pivot and retain momentum, but it is incompatible with Soft-Boiled and forces Clefairy to rely on Wish or Moonlight. Clefairy can also opt for a fully physically defensive spread to better check foes like Sawk and Silvally-Dark. A set with Calm Mind is also an option, although Clefairy is outclassed by Alcremie in this role.

Checks and Counters

Poison-types: Poison-types like Silvally-Poison, Skuntank, and Qwilfish force out Clefairy with their Poison-type STAB attacks and use that opportunity to set entry hazards or set up.

Steel-types: Although they dislike Knock Off, Steel-types like Alolan Sandslash and Perrserker are able to take advantage of Clefairy.

Fire-types: Fire-types like Ninetales and Rapidash resist Moonblast and can overwhelm Clefairy. However, they heavily dislike Knock Off removing their Heavy-Duty Boots and are susceptible to Toxic.

Strong Physical Attackers: Physical attackers like Kangaskhan, Silvally-Ground, and Thwackey exploit Clefairy's mediocre Defense and threaten to KO it.

Knock Off: Although Clefairy resists Knock Off, it is reliant on Eviolite to maintain its bulk; otherwise, it risks being overwhelmed by threats it is supposed to check, like Choice Specs Basculin and Thievul.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description:
Clefairy is a notable special wall in ZU, capable of checking foes like Thievul and Rotom and absorbing status from the likes of Wishiwashi and Altaria thanks to Magic Guard. Moonblast targets Dark- and Fighting-types like Alolan Persian, Liepard, and Sawk. Alternatively, Seismic Toss provides consistent damage output against foes that resist Moonblast, such as Qwilfish and Rapidash, while also breaking Substitute from threats like Frosmoth and Articuno. Knock Off cripples switch-ins like Qwilfish, Alolan Sandslash, and Rapidash. Toxic wears down problematic foes that can take advantage of Clefairy, like Silvally-Ground and Alcremie, and it synergizes with Seismic Toss, allowing Clefairy to take down most walls.

Clefairy fits best on balance and stall teams as a specially defensive wall. Ground-types like Rhydon, Piloswine, and Silvally-Ground can threaten Poison-, Steel-, and Fire-types that Clefairy has a hard time against. In return, it is able to take on foes like Articuno and Wishiwashi and absorb Toxic and burns from Scald. Physical walls such as Tangela and Cramorant are great partners for Clefairy, helping cover for its mediocre Defense and checking powerful wallbreakers such as Silvally-Ground and Kangaskhan. Knock Off absorbers like Alolan Persian and Qwilfish can help Clefairy preserve its Eviolite, which is crucial to keep checking special attackers. Wallbreakers such as Silvally formes, Cinccino, and Kangaskhan benefit from Clefairy's ability to whittle down defensive cores with Knock Off and Toxic.

Ninetales.comments:
Other Options

Flamethrower is an alternative to Fire Blast that provides more accuracy and consistency, but it is significantly weaker. Substitute can be used to avoid status from foes like Pyukumku and Altaria, while Agility helps Ninetales clean better late-game; however, Ninetales generally prefers retaining Scorching Sands.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Water-types like Wishiwashi, Poliwrath, and Cramorant can take Energy Ball and retaliate with a powerful Water-type STAB attack. However, they have difficulty checking Ninetales after Nasty Plot. Pyukumuku is notable, as it ignores Nasty Plot with Unaware and can stall Ninetales with Toxic + Recover.

Ground-types: Ground-types like Piloswine and Rhydon can threaten Ninetales with their STAB moves, but they should be wary of Energy Ball.

Revenge Killers: Foes such as Manectric, Cinccino, and Choice Scarf Sawk can outspeed and revenge kill Ninetales. It is also susceptible to priority from Kangaskhan, Gurdurr, and Shiftry if it is weakened.

Status: Ninetales is vulnerable to being worn down by Toxic from foes like Pyukumuku and Miltank, while Thunder Wave from Qwilfish cripples its Speed and makes it much easier to revenge kill.

Dragon-types: Altaria and Appletun resist or are immune to Ninetales's moves and can threaten it with a strong attack or status.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Ninetales is a notable sweeper thanks to its access to Nasty Plot, excellent coverage options, and good Speed tier. Nasty Plot lets Ninetales break through bulky walls such as Clefairy with its powerful Fire Blast and clean weakened teams. Energy Ball targets Water-types like Wishiwashi and Poliwrath and Ground-types like Rhydon, Piloswine, and Stunfisk. Scorching Sands is Ninetales's best move against Qwilfish and opposing Fire-types like Rapidash and Coalossal.

Ninetales fits on balance and offense teams as a mid- and late-game wallbreaker and revenge killer. Wallbreaking partners such as Rotom and Cinccino complement Ninetales; Rotom is able to threaten Water-types and safely bring in Ninetales with Volt Switch, while Cinccino is able to handle specially defensive walls like Pyukumuku and Miltank that wall Ninetales. In return, they benefit from its ability to handle Tangela and Eldegoss. Grass-types like Tangela and Eldegoss are also good partners, handling problematic foes like Stunfisk and Piloswine. Knock Off absorbers such as Uxie, Cofagrigus, and Qwilfish are necessary to preserve Heavy-Duty Boots and prevent Ninetales from being worn down by entry hazards; Uxie and Cofagrigus can also take on revenge killers such as Kangaskhan and Choice Scarf Sawk, while Qwilfish can provide entry hazard support to wear down foes like Piloswine and Poliwrath. Cleaners such as Frosmoth and Calm Mind Alcremie can take advantage of Ninetales's wallbreaking to set up and clean late-game.

Rapidash.comments:
Other Options

Solar Blade is an option on sun teams to surprise opposing Water- and Ground-types in one moveslot, but it is generally niche and requires dedicated support. Flame Charge allows Rapidash to boost its Speed and prevents it from being revenge killed by Choice Scarf users like Sawk and Rotom.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Although they dislike status and Wild Charge, Water-types like Wishiwashi, Qwilfish, and Poliwrath are able to handle Rapidash with their Water-type STAB attacks.

Rock- and Ground-types: Rock- and Ground-types like Coalossal and Rhydon threaten Rapidash and force it out. However, they must be wary of High Horsepower and a potential Will-O-Wisp if they are not immune to it.

Dragon-types: Dragon-types like Altaria and Appletun resist or are immune to Rapidash's Flare Blitz and coverage options. Although Appletun dislikes Toxic, Altaria can shrug off status thanks to Natural Cure.

Residual Damage: Toxic and Knock Off from Pokemon that Rapidash is supposed to check, like Articuno, Tangela, and Thwackey, can hinder its utility and effectiveness.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description:
Utility Rapidash is a solid check to prominent threats in ZU such as Frosmoth, Thwackey, and Articuno. High Horsepower targets Rock-types like Rhydon and Coalossal as well as Pokemon like Ninetales and Qwilfish. Toxic places checks such as Wishiwashi and Pyukumuku on a timer, while Will-O-Wisp cripples physical attackers like Kangaskhan, Piloswine, and Silvally formes. Morning Sun allows Rapidash to remain healthy throughout a match to continually soft check foes. Flash Fire provides an immunity to Fire-type moves, which allows Rapidash to handle Ninetales.

Utility Rapidash fits on bulky offense and balance teams as a check to many of ZU's prominent offensive threats. Tangela is an amazing partner, as it covers problematic Water- and Ground-types like Wishiwashi and Rhydon. In return, Rapidash is able to take on opposing Fire- and Ice-types and Eldegoss, which give Tangela trouble. This core is often paired with special walls like Clefairy and Wishiwashi to handle foes like special Basculin and Rotom. Ice-types like Frosmoth and Articuno can threaten the aforementioned Ground-types while also dealing with the problematic Altaria. Knock Off absorbers like Uxie and Qwilfish are necessary to preserve Rapidash's Heavy-Duty Boots, which is crucial to letting it consistently switch in.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
Swords Dance Rapidash is a wallbreaker and cleaner that faces competition with Ninetales as a Fire-type setup sweeper. High Horsepower targets foes like Rhydon, Coalossal, and Qwilfish. Morning Sun provides Rapidash with reliable recovery, mitigating some of the recoil from Flare Blitz and letting it consistently switch into foes like Frosmoth and Ninetales. Wild Charge handles opposing Water-types like Wishiwashi, Poliwrath, and Cramorant.

Swords Dance Rapidash functions best as a mid-game wallbreaker that can also double as a late-game cleaner. Grass-types like Tangela and Thwackey can help weaken Water-, Rock-, and Ground-types like Wishiwashi, Rhydon, and Piloswine; in return, they appreciate Rapidash forcing out Skuntank and Silvally-Poison and handling Tangela. Ice-types like Frosmoth, Articuno, and Aurorus threaten Dragon- and Water-types like Altaria, Appletun, and Poliwrath. Entry hazard support from Alolan Sandslash, Rhydon, and Qwilfish is valuable, wearing down physically bulky foes like Wishiwashi and Gurdurr into KO range. Likewise, special wallbreakers like Rotom, Basculin, and Skuntank can also pressure the aforementioned physical walls.

Tangela.comments:
Other Options

Tangela can run an offensive spread with a Modest nature, which makes it less passive while still being able to check most physical attackers. However, Tangela's coverage is narrow and can be easily walled; it's also forced to use Synthesis more often to maintain its HP. Stun Spore is an alternative over Sleep Powder or Toxic to paralyze foes, but crippling a foe with sleep or poison is usually preferred.

Checks and Counters

Special Attackers: Tangela has an abysmal special bulk and can be 2HKOed by almost any unresisted special attack. In particular, special attackers like Rotom-S and Skuntank have a great matchup against Tangela and can easily OHKO it. Strong special wallbreakers like Basculin are even able to break through Tangela with resisted attacks.

Item Removal: Without its Eviolite, Tangela is unable to reliably counter some physical attackers like Sawk. This is troublesome, as Tangela is often the preferred switch-in for common Knock Off users such as Sawk, Shiftry, and Cinccino.

Fire-types: Fire-types such as Rapidash and Ninetales can break through Tangela's huge physical bulk with their super effective STAB moves. However, they dislike losing their Heavy-Duty Boots to Knock Off.

Ice-types: Articuno and Alolan Sandslash threaten Tangela with their super effective STAB moves, while Frosmoth can use Tangela as setup fodder. They have to be wary of getting their item removed by Knock Off, though.

sets.name: Physical Wall
sets.description:
Tangela is an amazing physical wall thanks to its immense Eviolite-boosted physical bulk backed by Regenerator. This combination allows it to consistently absorb the hits of physical attackers such as Rhydon, Sawk, and Kangaskhan and regain the lost health by switching out. Giga Drain is the preferred STAB move for its additional recovery. Leaf Storm can be used instead for a powerful nuke, especially against Knock Off users like Sawk and Alolan Persian; the Special Attack drop isn't that crippling, as Tangela enjoys pivoting to regain HP with Regenerator. Knock Off lets Tangela cripple its checks such as Rapidash, Rotom-S, and Articuno. Sludge Bomb lets Tangela threaten Grass-types such as Shiftry and Flapple, which take little from Tangela's other moves and are immune to Sleep Powder and Leech Seed. Synthesis is Tangela's most reliable recovery move, letting it more comfortably check Choice Band Sawk and Kangaskhan, but Leech Seed can be used as an alternative, providing recovery to Tangela and chipping down its checks. Sleep Powder lets Tangela neutralize a foe to make pivoting easier, whereas Toxic puts walls that can otherwise take advantage of Tangela, such as Miltank and Uxie, on a timer.

Tangela is a great choice for many teams, ranging from stall to bulky offense, and it appreciates being paired with special walls such as Galarian Stunfisk, Wishiwashi, and Clefairy. Partners such as Qwilfish, Cramorant, and Altaria can handle Fire-types like Rapidash and Ninetales for Tangela, while it can take on the likes of Kangaskhan and Rhydon for them. Knock Off absorbers such as Silvally-Poison and Miltank are appreciated to preserve Tangela's Eviolite. Entry hazard supports from the likes of Uxie, Piloswine, and Clefairy is appreciated by Tangela, as it can remove Heavy-Duty Boots from checks like Altaria, Frosmoth, and Rotom-S, which are pressured by Stealth Rock without their item. Wallbreakers such as Thievul, Sawk, and Basculin value Tangela's ability to sponge hits for them when they are forced out.

Kangaskhan.comments:
Other Options

Body Slam is considerably weaker than Double-Edge, but Kangaskhan can use it instead for the paralysis chance and lack of recoil. Choice Band offers more immediate power and coverage, although the lack of reliable priority limits this set's potential. Substitute is an option to takes advantage of the switches Kangaskhan forces, and Power-Up Punch is another option for Kangaskhan to become a situational setup sweeper.

Checks and Counters

Physical Walls: Cofagrigus denies Scrappy with its own ability Mummy, allowing it to easily wall Kangaskhan and KO back with Body Press. Poliwrath, Uxie, and Alolan Persian are able to take hits from Kangaskhan and threaten back with Fighting-type coverage or pivoting. Tanks like Rhydon and Gurdurr also pose a threat to Kangaskhan.

Residual Damage: Kangaskhan's Fake Out is often punished by Rocky Helmet users like Miltank, and Qwilfish. Furthermore, Kangaskhan's entry hazard vulnerability and induced recoil from Double-Edge causes it to lose valuable chunks of HP and limits its turns on the field.

Revenge Killers: Faster attackers, especially ones able to take a Sucker Punch like Basculin, Silvally-Dark, and Choice Scarf Sawk are able to force out Kangaskhan. If Kangaskhan has an Adamant nature, more attackers like Rotom-S and Cramorant may also outspeed and deal with it.

sets.name: Priority Attacker
sets.description:
Kangaskhan is a dangerous priority attacker with wallbreaking potential when chaining together its STAB Fake Out and Double-Edge. It is thus equally prepared to check faster attackers like Basculin and Rotom and break special walls like Articuno and Clefairy. Sucker Punch combines with Fake Out for additional priority damage, and it is especially warranted to check setup sweepers like Silvally formes. Earthquake hits Steel- and Rock-types like Galarian Stunfisk, Coalossal, and Rhydon, and it avoids adverse contact effects from Rocky Helmet Qwilfish. Scrappy is essential to prevent frail Ghost-types from switching in and blocking Qwilfish's Intimidate. Silk Scarf improves Kangaskhan's main attacks. Heavy-Duty Boots instead combats Kangaskhan's residual damage vulnerability on teams with unreliable entry hazard control. A Jolly nature allows Kangaskhan to revenge kill Rotom-S and Choice Band Sawk more reliably, while Adamant picks up more KOs, like against Clefairy.

Entry hazards from Qwilfish, Alolan Sandslash, and Rhydon are invaluable to Kangaskhan, as it relies on the additional chip damage to stack with Fake Out and pressure more threats; Toxic Spikes from the first two is particularly potent. Another way to facilitate Fake Out is using defensive pivots such as Uxie, Alolan Persian, and Wishiwashi; these teammates are also valuable switch-ins when Kangaskhan is targeted by Sawk, Silvally formes, and Basculin. In return, these pivots rely on Kangaskhan to break walls that they are outstalled by and to punish threats like Frosmoth. Special wallbreakers like Choice Specs Basculin, Nasty Plot Skuntank, and Rotom break walls like Cofagrigus and Rhydon that Kangaskhan struggles with. Fake Out and Sucker Punch won't deal with every faster threat, so a Choice Scarf user like Sawk or Rotom should clean and revenge kill alongside Kangaskhan. Knock Off support from Clefairy, Gurdurr, and Shiftry removes Heavy-Duty Boots, Eviolite, and Leftovers from walls, making Kangaskhan more effective at wallbreaking Altaria, Tangela, and Wishiwashi.

Articuno.comments:
Other Options

Articuno can opt for a physically offensive set with options like Triple Axel, Brave Bird, and Ice Shard, but physical walls are more common, which makes special Articuno more effective at breaking through defensive cores.

Checks and Counters

Rock-type Pokemon and Coverage: Due to its 4x weakness to Rock, any Rock-type move will at least 2HKO Articuno. This makes Rock-types like Rhydon and Coalossal extremely annoying for Articuno, as they can easily set up entry hazards against it. Furthermore, Pokemon like Silvally-Ground and Miltank often carry Rock-type coverage, preventing Articuno from switching into them.

Item Removal: Retaining Heavy-Duty Boots is key to maintaining Articuno's defensive capabilities, and it should avoid switching into Knock Off and Trick users like Shiftry, Gurdurr, Thwackey, and Rotom. However, if Articuno is the team's entry hazard remover and is able to consistently use Defog against the opposing Stealth Rock setter, it can afford to lose its item.

Fire-types: Fire-types such as Ninetales and Rapidash force out Articuno with their super effective STAB move. However, they take great damage from Articuno's Flying-type STAB moves, and they dislike being crippled by Toxic.

Electric-types: Morpeko, Manectric, and Rotom formes threaten Articuno with their super effective STAB moves and generate momentum with Volt Switch. However, weaker Electric-types like Choice Scarf Rotom and defensive Rotom-S can't break through specially defensive Articuno.

Steel-types: Steel-types such as Perrserker, Alolan Sandslash, and Klinklang are immune to Toxic, resist Articuno's STAB moves, and take on Articuno with their super effective STAB moves.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description:
Articuno is an amazing special wall and one of the best form of entry hazard control in ZU thanks to Pressure + Defog keeping entry hazards off the field against numerous setters such as Qwilfish, Uxie, and Clefairy, its amazing bulk, and reliable recovery in Roost. Freeze-Dry lets Articuno threaten entry hazard setters like Qwilfish and Stunfisk, as well as Pokemon that can freely switch into its other moves like Tangela and Altaria. Alternatively, Brave Bird is the preferred STAB move to check Frosmoth. Toxic wears down opposing walls such as Cramorant and entry hazard setters such as Coalossal and Rhydon, which forces Articuno out, while U-turn turns Articuno into a pivot. Articuno can also run Haze to stop Stored Power users like Alcremie and Uxie or Heal Bell to act as a cleric. The given EV spread lets Articuno outspeed Adamant Trevenant. Alternatively, Articuno can run 136 Speed EVs with a Jolly nature to outspeed Flapple and Adamant Shiftry.

Specially defensive Articuno fits on almost any kind of team, ranging from stall to bulky offense. On offensive teams, it forms a VoltTurn core with partners like Silvally-Ground, Uxie, and Alolan Persian. Frail attackers such as Basculin, Cinccino, and Shiftry enjoy safely coming on the field through these VoltTurn cores and benefit from slower pivots like Articuno sponging attacks for them. Knock Off absorbers like Qwilfish, Pyukumuku, and Silvally formes are great partners that can preserve Articuno's Heavy-Duty Boots and sponge physical hits, while it handles special attackers for them. Ground-types like Rhydon, Stunfisk, and Vibrava make for excellent partners for their ability to handle Articuno's weaknesses, while they appreciate Articuno checking Frosmoth and specially offensive Basculin.

sets.name: SubRoost
sets.description:
The combination of Substitute, Roost, and Pressure lets Articuno stall out moves with low PP such as Ninetales's Fire Blast, Kabutop's Stone Edge, and Trevenant's Poltergeist. Thanks to its great Speed and bulk, Articuno is able to easily set up a Substitute against passive Pokemon such as Tangela, Eldegoss, and Qwilfish. Toxic works well with the combination of Roost + Substitute, racking up damage on foes like Coalossal, Uxie, and Kangaskhan. Freeze-Dry is the preferred STAB move to cover Qwilfish, Wishiwashi, and Altaria, which can sponge Toxic.

SubRoost Articuno fits well on balance and bulky offense teams looking for a Pokemon that does well against balance teams. Knock Off absorbers like Silvally formes, Qwilfish, and Alolan Persian are appreciated to preserve Articuno's Heavy-Duty Boots. VoltTurn users like Basculin, Manectric, and Uxie safely bring Articuno onto the field, letting it avoid Knock Off from the likes of Tangela and Uxie. Ground-types such as Silvally-Ground, Rhydon, and Stunfisk make for great partners, checking Steel-, Fire-, Rock-, and Ground-types such as Perrserker, Coalossal, and Rhydon. In return, Articuno checks Water- and Grass-types such as Qwilfish, Appletun, and Flapple for them. Checks to Steel-types like Sawk, Rapidash, and Manectric are especially important, since Steel-types like Klinklang and Perrserker completely shut down SubRoost Articuno.

sets.name: Roost + 3 Attacks
sets.description:
Articuno is a great offensive pivot that is able to dish out powerful Hurricanes and Freeze-Drys. The given EV investment in conjunction with its coverage allows Articuno to outspeed and nail threats such as Thwackey, Poliwrath, and Gurdurr. Thanks to U-turn, Articuno is able to pivot from bad matchups and safely bring in partners.

Roost + 3 Attacks Articuno fits on offensive teams with VoltTurn cores, which makes Uxie, Rotom, and Wishiwashi great partners. Articuno also excels on entry hazard stacking teams, since it preys on common Defoggers such as Cramorant and Altaria and is able to generate momentum with U-turn. Physical wallbreakers such as Kangaskhan, Cinccino, and Silvally formes can take advantage of Articuno inviting in and pivoting against special walls such as Coalossal, Clefairy, and Alolan Sandslash. In return, Articuno can threaten physical walls such as Qwilfish, Wishiwashi, and Tangela for them. Ground-types like Silvally-Ground and Rhydon are great partners, checking Rock-, Fire-, Steel-, and Electric-types such as Coalossal, Klinklang, and Stunfisk. Knock Off absorbers like Uxie, Alolan Persian, and Qwilfish let Articuno keep its Heavy-Duty Boots.

Qwilfish.comments:
Other Options

A Swords Dance set can act as a terrifying stallbreaker with Qwilfish's Toxic immunity and access to Taunt. However, it lacks bulk and power, even when boosted. Qwilfish can run max Speed on its defensive set to outspeed attackers like Skuntank and Adamant Kangaskhan; however, that jeopardizes its ability to handle physical attackers. Such sets can run Destiny Bond to get an unexpected KO, but Qwilfish usually doesn't have the room for it and is required to run an inferior max Speed spread. Although weaker than Liquidation, Waterfall is an option on both sets for its flinch chance and synergy with Thunder Wave. Poison Jab is also an alternative to the STAB moves on defensive sets for its ability to damage Water-resistant attackers like Exeggutor, Basculin, and Shiftry and spread poison. However, Thunder Wave and Scald already spread status and cripple those Pokemon.

Checks and Counters

Uxie: Thanks to Levitate, Uxie isn't affected by Qwilfish's entry hazards and can heavily damage it with Psychic, while Qwilfish hardly hurts Uxie with its moves. Uxie's Future Sight is also a huge threat to Qwilfish, as it prevents Qwilfish from switching into threats it is supposed to counter, such as Rapidash and Gurdurr.

Ground-immune Entry Hazard Removers: Entry hazard removers such as Rotom, Rotom-S, Altaria, and Cryogonal aren't affected by Spikes and threaten Qwilfish with their powerful special attacks. They can easily force Qwilfish out and use that opportunity to remove its entry hazards.

Special Attackers: Qwilfish's special bulk is underwhelming, meaning that special attackers such as Thievul, Rotom, and Articuno can easily OHKO it.

Ground-types: Qwilfish is weak to Ground-types and cannot handle crucial physical attackers such as Rhydon and Piloswine, even if they are 2HKOed by Qwilfish's Water-type STAB moves. Qwilfish also takes heavy damage from common Ground-type coverage from wallbreakers like Rapidash and Sawk; the latter is noteworthy due to Inner Focus ignoring Intimidate.

Strong Physical Wallbreakers: Even with Intimidate, Qwilfish's bulk isn't amazing and, without any reliable recovery moves, it is quickly put in range of powerful wallbreakers like Kangaskhan, Choice Band Cinccino, and Swords Dance Silvally formes.

sets.name: Defensive Spikes
sets.description:
Qwilfish is a premier physical wall that is able to set Spikes or Toxic Spikes and counter powerful physical attackers such as Basculin and Sawk. Its typing also lets it absorb Toxic Spikes from opposing Qwilfish and Cofagrigus. Thanks to Taunt, Qwilfish can prevent slower Pokémon such as Cofagrigus, Pyukumuku, and Clefairy from setting up, recovering HP, and setting entry hazards. Thunder Wave cripples faster attackers such as Skuntank, specially offensive Basculin, and Articuno, which can otherwise freely switch into Qwilfish. Liquidation is the preferred STAB move for its ability to OHKO Rapidash and Ninetales after minimal residual damage. Scald is another option that, while significantly weaker, can cripple switch-ins with a burn. Pain Split improves Qwilfish's longevity versus bulkier teams. Rocky Helmet lets Qwilfish wear down physical attackers, punishing resisted moves like Gurdurr's Mach Punch, Alolan Sandslash's Triple Axel, and Basculin's Flip Turn. Alternatively, Black Sludge makes Qwilfish less reliant on Pain Split. The given EV spread lets Qwilfish outspeed Adamant Alolan Sandslash and maximize its physical bulk.

Qwilfish fits well on bulky offense and balance teams that appreciate its defensive utility and ability to set entry hazards. Special walls like Articuno, Stunfisk, and Alolan Sandslash make for great partners, as they are able to handle special attackers like Frosmoth, Rotom, and Frosmoth; in return, Qwilfish handles physical attackers such as Sawk and Rapidash. Ground-immune and -resistant Pokemon such as Rotom-S, Uxie, and Tangela cover Qwilfish's Ground weakness. VoltTurn cores pair well with Spikes, as they force a lot of switches. Therefore, Pokemon such as Rotom, Silvally-Dark, and Cinccino make for great partners. Spikes are appreciated by wallbreakers like Rapidash and Sawk; Kangaskhan is a noteworthy example, as it can force switches thanks to Fake Out. Knock Off users such as Shiftry, Thwackey, and Gurdurr can remove opposing Heavy-Duty Boots, bolstering the effectiveness of Qwilfish's entry hazards.

Piloswine.comments:
Other Options

Toxic allows Piloswine to wear down foes like Cofagrigus, Poliwrath, Pyukumuku, and Wishiwashi. Rock Slide provides coverage against Frosmoth and Articuno.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Bulky Water-types like Poliwrath, Wishiwashi, Pyukumuku, and Cramorant are able to switch into Piloswine and force it out, with Cramorant also removing Stealth Rock. Although they cannot directly switch into Piloswine, offensive Water-types like Basculin and Ludicolo can threaten to KO it.

Fighting-types and Fighting-type Coverage: Fighting-types like Sawk, Gurdurr, and Poliwrath pressure Piloswine immensely. Pokemon that carry Fighting-type coverage like Body Press Cofagrigus also threaten Piloswine.

Grass-types: Even though they cannot switch into Piloswine and fear being revenge killed by Ice Shard if weakened, Shiftry and Tangela are able to threaten Piloswine. Tangela is able to tank hits from Piloswine and cripple it with Toxic and Knock Off or KO it with Leaf Storm or Giga Drain.

Residual Damage: Given Piloswine's lack of recovery, residual damage from entry hazards and status can wear it down over the course of the battle.

sets.name: Stealth Rock
sets.description:
Piloswine's typing, huge bulk, and Thick Fat let it serve as a Stealth Rock setter that has good matchups against some Stealth Rock setters such as Rhydon and Galarian Stunfisk. Earthquake and Icicle Crash form a formidable STAB combination, hitting relevant targets such as Skuntank, Silvally formes, and Rotom-S. Ice Shard allows Piloswine to revenge kill weakened foes such as Shiftry and Rotom. Thick Fat lets Piloswine switch into the likes of Rapidash and Aurorus.

Piloswine fits best on bulky offensive teams that appreciate its ability to take hits and consistently set Stealth Rock. Water-types such as Wishiwashi, Poliwrath, and Cramorant are problematic for Piloswine; checks to them such as Eldegoss and Cramorant are appreciated. Fighting-types like Sawk, Gurdurr, and the aforementioned Poliwrath greatly pressure Piloswine. Partners such as Rotom-S and Qwilfish can alleviate this weakness; the former can provide VoltTurn support, while the latter can wear down problematic foes such as Cofagrigus and Miltank with Spikes and Toxic Spikes.

Shiftry.comments:
Other Options

Swords Dance variants can run Leaf Blade over Leaf Storm to have a more consistent Grass STAB move to clean, better dealing with walls such as Poliwrath and Carbink. However, Leaf Blade is worse at wallbreaking in the early- and mid-game because it lacks raw power and relies on Swords Dance.

Checks and Counters

Colbur Berry: Thanks to Colbur Berry, Uxie and Cofagrigus can stomach a boosted Knock Off from Shiftry and OHKO it back with U-turn and Body Press respectively.

Dark-resistant Pokemon: Dark-resistant foes such as Silvally-Dark, Gurdurr, and Alcremie can comfortably take Shiftry's Knock Off and OHKO Shiftry with their super effective moves. However, most of these Pokemon have to watch out for Shiftry's less spammable Leaf Storm, which can heavily damage them, and are obliterated by a boosted Solar Blade.

U-turn: Shiftry's 4x weakness to Bug makes it extremely susceptible to common U-turn users such as Silvally-Dark, Liepard, and Cinccino.

Faster Attackers: While Shiftry's Sucker Punch is very powerful and able to easily clean teams after a single Swords Dance, it is not strong enough to threaten faster Pokemon when unboosted. Therefore, faster attackers such as Silvally-Poison, Articuno, and Rotom-S can force Shiftry out.

Priority Moves: While Shiftry resists Thwackey's Grassy Glide and opposing Shiftry's Sucker Punch, it takes heavy damage from other priority moves such as Kangaskhan's Fake Out, which can pick off a very weakened Shiftry in sun. Alolan Sandslash's and Piloswine's Ice Shard and Gurdurr's Mach Punch are noteworthy, as they need significantly less chip damage to take out Shiftry.

sets.name: Mixed Attacker
sets.description:
Shiftry is a powerful mixed attacker and stallbreaker thanks to its amazing offensive typing letting it threaten common walls such as Uxie, Wishiwashi, and Cofagrigus. Sucker Punch lets Shiftry pick off faster attackers that have been weakened, such as Rotom, Cinccino, and Basculin. Leaf Storm acts as a powerful special nuke, heavily damaging physical walls such as Qwilfish, Gurdurr, and Cofagrigus. Swords Dance lets Shiftry act as a late-game cleaner by empowering its Sucker Punch and also lets it wallbreak more easily with Knock Off, OHKOing Altaria that have been weakened after a Swords Dance. Defog is an alternative if the team lacks a Defogger and takes advantage of Shiftry's good matchup against common entry hazard setters such as Rhydon and Uxie.

Shiftry is a good pick for any offensive team looking for a strong wallbreaker with a great stall matchup. Qwilfish is an amazing partners that punishes U-turn with Rocky Helmet; in return, Shiftry improves the effectiveness of its Spikes by removing Heavy-Duty Boots from Pokemon like Rapidash with Knock Off. Other physical wallbreakers such as Silvally formes, Sawk, and Cinccino appreciate Shiftry weakening physical walls such as Tangela with the combination of Knock Off and Leaf Storm. Shiftry also appreciate VoltTurn support from users such as Basculin, Uxie, and Rotom, which can safely bring it onto the field. Faster threats that resist Sucker Punch, like Sawk and Alolan Persian, are able to consistently force out Shiftry; therefore, checks to them like Rotom-S and Poliwrath are appreciated.

sets.name: Sun Sweeper
sets.description:
Shiftry is a powerhouse in sun, outspeeding the whole unboosted metagame and most Choice Scarf users. Shiftry's deadly STAB combination lets it OHKO most Pokemon it outspeeds, and it can easily break through defensive teams after a Swords Dance or Growth. Sucker Punch lets Shiftry revenge kill faster attackers when sun is not up. Sun-boosted Heat Wave lets Shiftry OHKO strong physical walls that can take its other moves, such as Shiinotic and Tangela.

Shiftry is a staple on sun teams due to it raw power and lack of offensive and defensive checks under sun. Sun setters such as Uxie, Liepard, and Exeggutor make for great partners that enables Shiftry to wallbreak or sweep. The former two can even safely bring Shiftry onto the field with U-turn. Other Chlorophyll users such as Exeggutor can also take advantage of sun and form a Grass spam core with Shiftry, weakening each other's checks. Fire-types like Ninetales and Rapidash can also utilize sun to boost their STAB moves and weaken Shiftry's checks like opposing Fire-types, Piloswine, and Gurdurr.

Manectric.comments:
Other Options

Toxic is an option to cripple counters like Rhydon, Piloswine, and Appletun without getting rid of its Choice item with Switcheroo. However, Switcheroo is more consistent,(AC) as being locked on Toxic can invite threats in. Manectric can run a Heavy-Duty Boots set with Toxic over Switcheroo; however, it lacks the power of Choice Specs and Speed of Choice Scarf, making it hard to justify.

Checks and Counters

Ground-types: Ground-types like Stunfisk, Rhydon, and Piloswine are immune to Manectric's STAB moves and OHKO it. However, Galarian Stunfisk have to watch out for Choice Specs-boosted Fire-type coverage, while Rhydon and Piloswine dislike getting their Eviolite removed by Switcheroo.

Special Walls: Special walls like Eldegoss and Clefairy are able to sponge Manectric's hits, and the former two can even nullify the chip damage from Volt Switch with Regenerator. Appletun, in particular, resists every move from Manectric and mitigates damage with Recover. However, they dislike losing their items to Switcheroo.

Priority Users: Due to Manectric's lackluster bulk, it gets easily removed by priority users such as Choice Band Thwackey, Kangaskhan, and Shiftry after chip damage.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Manectric is a potent Choice Scarf user thanks to its high Speed letting it outspeed sweepers like +1 Silvally formes and Choice Scarf Sawk, great Electric + Fire coverage, and Volt Switch. Additionally, it brings a valuable Electric immunity thanks to Lightning Rod letting it absorb Volt Switch from Rotom formes. Overheat provides coverage for Electric-resistant foes like Eldegoss, Galarian Stunfisk, and Tangela. If Manectric's high Speed tier isn't needed anymore, it can use Switcheroo to cripple special walls such as Stunfisk, Clefairy, and Rhydon.

Manectric is a great choice for VoltTurn teams looking for a revenge killer and Electric immunity. Additional VoltTurn users such as Uxie, Articuno, Wishiwashi, and Alolan Persian are appreciated. The aforementioned ones are especially great, as they can sponge hits for Manectric, making up for its lackluster bulk, and wear down Ground-types such as Rhydon, Stunfisk, and Piloswine. Physical wallbreakers like Basculin, Kangaskhan, and Sawk can take advantage of special walls that Manectric forces in and pivots against with Volt Switch. Entry hazard support from partners like Alolan Sandslash, Coalossal, and Qwilfish benefits Manectric by letting it take more advantage of Volt Switch and guaranteeing OHKOs against Tangela.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Manectric is a powerful Choice Specs user thanks to its great offensive stats and Electric + Fire coverage, which let it threaten common defensive cores like Articuno + Qwilfish + Galarian Stunfisk. Choice Specs-boosted Volt Switch whittles down special walls like Clefairy, Throh, and Appletun while retaining momentum. Overheat allows Manectric to OHKO threats like Flapple and Rotom and break down Ground-types such as Galarian Stunfisk. Flamethrower is an alternative that doesn't drop Manectric's Special Attack, which makes it more spammable, but it does not break down Volt Switch switch-ins as effectively as Overheat. Switcheroo lets Manectric cripple checks like Eldegoss, Piloswine, and Rhydon, which it is unable to break through, at the cost giving up Choice Specs.

Manectric fits at best on VoltTurn cores with partners like Basculin, Articuno, and Uxie, chipping down the opposing team through constant pivoting. Spikes support from Qwilfish or Alolan Sandslash helps this process by further weakening the foes, putting foes like Sawk and Flapple into OHKO range. Physical wallbreakers like Sawk, Thwackey, and Shiftry can take advantange of special walls and Ground-types that Manectric forces in and benefit from its ability to safely bring them in. Special cleaners like Choice Scarf Basculin, Nasty Plot Liepard, and Frosmoth enjoy Manectric weakening special walls, making it easier for them to clean late-game.

Altaria.comments:
Other Options

The combination of Fire Spin and Perish Song lets Altaria trap and take out walls such as Musharna and Pyukumuku; however, this set lacks the utility of Defog and only traps a limited number of Pokemon. Draco Meteor is Altaria's strongest move, but it is less consistent than Hurricane and Dual Wingbeat due to the Special Attack drop. Heal Bell can be used on stall teams lacking a cleric.

Checks and Counters

Ice-types and Ice-type Coverage: Altaria's 4x weakness to Ice makes it extremely vulnerable to any Ice-type attacks. Altaria is threatened by Ice-types such as Frosmoth, Arctovish, and Rotom-F, but it also has to watch out for Ice coverage from attackers such as Basculin and Poliwrath.

Rock-types: Rock-types such as Kabutops and Rhydon threaten Altaria with Stone Edge and can safely set up Stealth Rock versus Altaria.

Dragon-types: Due to its weakness to Dragon, powerful Dragon-type wallbreakers like Flapple and Appletun can break through Altaria with their STAB moves, even if they can't switch into Altaria's Hurricane.

Fairy-types: Fairy-types such as Clefairy and Alcremie pressure Altaria with their super effective STAB move, and they aren't pressured by Toxic thanks to Magic Guard and Aromatherapy, respectively. They can even take advantage of Altaria to set up with Calm Mind.

Setup Sweepers: While Altaria's bulk is great, it gets easily overwhelmed by strong attackers that can set up such as Silvally-Dark, Rotom-S, and Shiftry.

sets.name: Physical Wall
sets.description:
Altaria is a premier wall in ZU thanks to its ability to reliably answer powerful physical and special attackers such as Thwackey, Ninetales, and Sawk. Toxic allows Altaria to put foes on a timer, letting it comfortably use Defog against entry hazard setters such as Piloswine and Miltank. Hurricane is Altaria's strongest STAB move, letting it threaten foes such as Qwilfish, Gurdurr, and Thwackey. Flamethrower is an alternative that targets Steel-types such as Alolan Sandslash and Klinklang, which can otherwise maintain hazards up versus Altaria. Likewise, Earthquake targets Toxic-immune foes such as Skuntank and Perrserker, while allowing Altaria to take on Fire-types more easily. The given EV spread allows Altaria to outspeed Adamant Perrserker and avoid the 2HKO from Choice Specs Thievul while maximizing its physical bulk.

Altaria is an excellent pick for balance and stall teams looking for a Defogger and a check to Fire-types. Offensive Fire-types like Rapidash and Ninetales can take advantage of Altaria's checks such as Clefairy, Rhydon, and Frosmoth while benefitting from Altaria walling opposing Fire- and Water-types. These two are also checks to Ice-types, and additional checks such as Piloswine, Poliwrath, and Miltank make for great partners, handling Altaria's biggest weakness. Other walls such as Pyukumuku, Rhydon, and Alolan Persian appreciate Altaria's ability to absorb status for them; in return, they can handle threats that Altaria struggles with such as Alolan Sandslash and Flapple. Choice Scarf users such as Sawk and Rotom can revenge kill the threats that can muscle through Altaria.

Skuntank.comments:
Other Options

Life Orb provides additional damage output, but the recoil damage limits Skuntank's longevity and makes it prone to entry hazards. Defog and Heavy-Duty Boots turn Skuntank into an offensive entry hazard remover, but this makes it inconsistent in its stallbreaking role.

Checks and Counters

Ground-types: Ground-types such as Rhydon, Stunfisk, and Piloswine are able to take a boosted hit from Skuntank and OHKO it back with their STAB moves.

Faster Offensive Threats: Skuntank's mediocre Speed leaves it susceptible to faster attackers such as Rapidash, Kangskhan, and Cinccino. Special wallbreakers and pivots like Rotom and Basculin can also threaten to revenge kill Skuntank, preventing it from consistently performing its role. However, physical attackers should be wary of residual damage from Aftermath.

Special Walls: Although they do not appreciate Taunt and being poisoned by Sludge Bomb, special walls such as Wishiwashi and Type: Null are able to take boosted hits from Skuntank and pivot with U-turn, safely bringing in revenge killers to threaten it. Steel-types like Alolan Sandslash and Galarian Stunfisk are able to wear down Skuntank if it lacks Fire Blast.

sets.name: Stallbreaker
sets.description:
Skuntank is a great stallbreaker in ZU; its Poison / Dark typing gives it various opportunities to set up against foes such as Uxie and Tangela. While initially weak, Skuntank can pummel passive walls like Clefairy and Cofagrigus with Nasty Plot and its STAB coverage. Taunt can be used to prevent foes like Miltank and Pyukumuku from recovering HP and setup sweepers like Quiver Dance Frosmoth from setting up. Alternatively, Fire Blast helps Skuntank better break through Alolan Sandslash and Frosmoth and 2HKOes Galarian Stunfisk after a Nasty Plot boost.

Skuntank fits best on offense and balance teams that appreciate its Toxic and Psychic immunities, stallbreaking, and ability to pressure Ghost-, Psychic-, and Fairy-types like Cofagrigus, Uxie, and Clefairy. Ground-types such as Rhydon, Stunfisk, and Piloswine are able to heavily pressure Skuntank; checks to them such as Basculin and Cramorant are appreciated. The aforementioned Water-types can also lure in Grass-types like Eldegoss and Tangela for Skuntank to take advantage of. Partners like Sawk and Swords Dance Silvally formes benefit from Skuntank weakening foes such as Tangela, Qwilfish, and Alcremie to clean late-game.

Spiritomb.comments:
Other Options

Spiritomb can run a physical wallbreaker set with Choice Band thanks to powerful moves in Poltergeist and Sucker Punch. Choice Band also pairs well with Trick, as it lets Spiritomb cripple the few Pokemon that can safely switch into Poltergeist such as Miltank and Tangela. However, Spiritomb is too slow to be a real offensive threat and being Choice-locked into Sucker Punch makes it very exploitable.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Dark-types such as Shiftry, Skuntank, and Silvally-Dark resist Spiritomb's Dark Pulse and use it as setup fodder or, in Alolan Persian's case, beat it with the combination of Taunt + Toxic.

Wallbreakers: With no way of boosting its average physical bulk and Rest as its only form of recovery, Spiritomb gets overpowered by strong physical wallbreakers such as Flapple, Basculin, and Silvally formes. Spiritomb's special bulk is also lackluster before setting up a Calm Mind, and it can be forced out by special wallbreakers like Choice Specs Rotom and Basculin.

Alcremie: Alcremie is able to use Spiritomb as setup fodder for its Calm Mind sets and defeat it with Dazzling Gleam, while it is unable to do much in return. It should, however, be noted that mono-attacking variants of Alcremie running Stored Power get PP stalled by Spiritomb.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description:
Spiritomb is a fearsome defensive Calm Mind sweeper that is able to find setup opportunities against some threats like Sawk locked into Close Combat, Swoobat, and Cofagrigus. Dark Pulse is the preferred STAB move, as, unlike Shadow Ball, it has no immunities. Rest is Spiritomb's most reliable recovery move and lets it get rid of status. Sleep Talk prevents Spritomb from being completely passive during Rest. Pressure lets Spiritomb PP stall defensive walls like Throh and Clefairy.

Spiritomb fits best on stall teams where its initial passivity isn't as crippling, and its unique defensive utility and PP stalling capabilities are appreciated. On these teams, Spiritomb's teammates whittle down and remove its counters over the course of a match, so it can be used as a late-game wincon. Physical walls like Pyukumuku, Tangela, and Altaria handle powerful wallbreakers such as Basculin and Silvally formes. Special walls like Clefairy and Eldegoss are necessary to handle special wallbreakers such as Ninetales and Basculin, which can force out an unboosted Spiritomb. Some of them even provide Heal Bell support to wake up Spiritomb after it uses Rest. Checks to Dark-types like Alcremie, Mawile, and Throh are appreciated for their ability to take on foes such as Skuntank and Shiftry, which use Spiritomb as setup fodder. Checks to Alcremie such as Pyukumuku and Haze Articuno are also necessary, as it is a major threat to stall teams and can freely come in on Spiritomb.

Leafeon.comments:
Other Options

Weather Ball targets physically defensive Grass-types like Tangela, Thwackey, and Gourgeist-S, but they already do not appreciate taking a Knock Off or Double-Edge. Synthesis provides Leafeon with sun-boosted recovery and counteracts the residual damage from Life Orb.

Checks and Counters

Grass-resistant Pokemon: Pokemon such as Altaria, Gourgeist-XL, and Tangela resist Solar Blade and are able to pressure Leafeon with status. However, they dislike being crippled by Knock Off and weakened by Double-Edge.

Poison-types: Although they do not appreciate Knock Off or Double-Edge, Poison-types such as Silvally-Poison and Skuntank are able to take unboosted hits from Leafeon and retaliate with their STAB moves.

Fire-types: Fire-types such as Ninetales and Rapidash threaten Leafeon, although they must be wary of Knock Off and Double-Edge.

Residual Damage and Priority: Recoil from Life Orb and Double-Edge, as well as residual damage from entry hazards, limits Leafeon's survivability and makes it susceptible to being revenge killed by foes such as Kangaskhan and Piloswine.

sets.name: Sun Sweeper
sets.description:
Leafeon finds a niche on sun teams as a physical sweeper, utilizing its bulk to set up with Swords Dance and threaten foes with a Life Orb-boosted Solar Blade. Leaf Blade is a notable alternative over Solar Blade that, despite its lower damage output, provides a reliable STAB attack when sun is not up. Knock Off allows Leafeon to weaken Grass-resistant foes such as Ninetales, Tangela, and Silvally-Poison. Double-Edge gives Leafeon coverage against problematic foes like Skuntank, Altaria, and the aforementioned Ninetales and Silvally-Poison.

Sun setters such as Uxie, Liepard, and Exeggutor are mandatory, as they enable Leafeon to outspeed the entire unboosted metagame and let it utilize Solar Blade. Leafeon can form an attacking core with other sun sweepers such as Shiftry and Ivysaur, with all weakening each other's shared checks in Pokemon such as Skuntank. Fire-types such as Ninetales and Rapidash can also take advantage of sun to boost their STAB moves and threaten foes such as Eldegoss and Tangela. Ground-types such as Piloswine and Rhydon can take advantage of Poison- and Fire-types that Leafeon invites in and use that opportunity to fire off a strong hit or set Stealth Rock; in return, they appreciate Leafeon threatening opposing Water-types like Wishiwashi and Basculin.

Rotom-Fan.comments:
Other Options

Thunder Wave and Toxic are valid replacements for Will-O-Wisp, but the former is punished by switching into Ground-types, which already don’t fear Rotom-S's other moves, and the latter allows switch-ins such as Alolan Sandslash and Galarian Stunfisk to come in more easily. Discharge can used as Rotom-S's Electric-type STAB move to paralyze offensive switch-ins but leaves it worse off versus bulkier Pokemon. Rotom-S can be a team's Choice Scarf user, but its weakness to Stealth Rock, vulnerability to common priority moves such as Ice Shard, and direct competition with Rotom make it suboptimal for that role.

Checks and Counters

Bulky Ground-types: Ground-types such as Piloswine, Galarian Stunfisk, and Rhydon block Rotom-S's Volt Switch and Thunderbolt and take little from Air Slash. All of them, however, don’t appreciate taking a Will-O-Wisp on the switch.

Revenge Killers: Faster attackers with moves to hit Rotom-S hard such as Cinccino and Silvally formes are able to pressure it out with ease.

Toxic: Taking Toxic from users such as Altaria, Alolan Persian, and Miltank cripples Rotom-S due to its unreliable recovery.

Knock Off: Knock Off users like Sawk, Thwackey, and Gurdurr are difficult for Rotom-S to consistently switch into. Entry hazard setters with access to Knock Off such as Uxie, Clefairy, and Alolan Sandslash also make it hard for Rotom-S to consistently remove entry hazards throughout a game.

sets.name: Defog
sets.description:
Rotom-S is one of the premier entry hazard removers in the metagame due to its ability to pivot with Volt Switch and excellent defensive typing that lets it wall and threaten common Pokemon such as Qwilfish and Sawk. Will-O-Wisp allows Rotom-S to cripple physical attackers such as Kangaskhan, Silvally formes, and Rhydon on the switch, while Pain Split gives greater but unreliable longevity. 252 Speed EVs let Rotom-S outspeed relevant Pokemon such as Cramorant, Qwilfish, and Choice Band Sawk. Investing in Special Attack over HP to pressure common walls like Altaria, Cofagrigus, and Piloswine is also viable.

Rotom-S fits on balance and offense teams as an entry hazard remover and pivot. Common VoltTurn teammates like Silvally-Dark, Wishiwashi, and Uxie can form a pivot core with Rotom-S to safely bring in wallbreakers such as Frosmoth and Shiftry. Toxic cripples Rotom-S, so Toxic-immune partners such as Qwilfish, Clefairy, and Alolan Sandslash are greatly appreciated; Rotom-S in turn provides them with a switch-in to Ground-type attacks. Knock Off hinders Rotom-S's ability to remove entry hazards, so Knock Off absorbers such as Silvally formes, Qwilfish, and Skuntank help immensely. Rotom-S is unable to deal with hard-hitting wallbreakers such as Kangaskhan, Silvally formes, and Rapidash, so strong revenge killers such as Cinccino, Alolan Persian, and Choice Scarf Sawk are all great teammates.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Rotom-S's decent Speed along with an excellent offensive typing give it a niche as a stallbreaker and cleaner with Nasty Plot. Substitute allows Rotom-S to avoid crippling status from passive Pokemon such as Clefairy and Altaria, which, in conjunction with its STAB Thunderbolt, lets it beat the only Unaware user in the tier in Pyukumuku. Pain Split, on the other hand, gives Rotom-S more longevity against weak attackers without status such as Cofagrigus, Galarian Stunfisk, and Uxie.

Rotom-S is fits on offensive teams for its stallbreaking and cleaning capabilities. Teammates such as Silvally formes, Kangaskhan, and Basculin appreciate Rotom-S dealing with bulky Pokemon such as Pyukumuku, Tangela, and Altaria. Faster offensive Pokemon such as Kangaskhan, Rapidash, and Silvally formes are able to threaten Rotom-S, so switch-ins such as Cofagrigus, Piloswine, and Galarian Stunfisk and fast attackers like Alolan Persian, Basculin, and Choice Scarf Sawk are vital for it. Ground-type Pokemon such as Piloswine and Rhydon are able to stomach an unboosted attack from Rotom-S, so switch-ins such as Wishiwashi, Tangela, and Miltank are appreciated.

Liepard.comments:
Other Options

Liepard has other useful support options like Taunt and Thunder Wave; however, it lacks room for them.

Checks and Counters

Fighting- and Fairy-types: Sawk, Poliwrath, and Alcremie take little from Liepard's moves and OHKO it back with their STAB moves. Gurdurr easily tanks Dark Pulse and OHKOes Liepard after slight chip damage.

Special Walls: Nasty Plot sets need several boosts to break through special walls such as Articuno and Wishiwashi, which can stall Liepard with Toxic or outright 2HKO it with their attacks.

Dark-types: Dark-types like Shiftry, Silvally-Dark, and Skuntank are immune to Prankster, resist Liepard's STAB moves, and defeat it with their secondary STAB or coverage moves. However, they have to watch out for U-turn.

Strong Attackers: Because of its poor bulk, Liepard gets OHKOed by strong attackers like Kangaskhan, Silvally formes, and Basculin. Liepard is forced out by them unless it manages to lock them into unfavorable moves with Encore.

sets.name: Sun Setter
sets.description:
The combination of Prankster and Sunny Day lets Liepard act as an excellent mid-game sun setter. U-turn lets it pivot into a teammate that benefits from sun, such as Shiftry and Ivysaur. Knock Off helps Liepard further support its teammates by removing Heavy-Duty Boots from Articuno and Altaria. Encore locks foes such as Silvally-Poison and Uxie into unfavorable moves like Work Up and Stealth Rock, giving Liepard free turns to set up sun and pivot with U-turn. Heat Rock is necessary to provide as many sun turns as possible to Liepard's partners.

Liepard is a must-have on sun teams and is appreciated by sun sweepers such as Shiftry, Ivysaur, and Rapidash. Uxie's sun setter set also fits well on sun teams for its capacity to reliably set Stealth Rock and sun for its team. Furthermore, a third sun setter such as Exeggutor provides more possibilities to set up sun.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Thanks to its high Speed tier and access to Nasty Plot and a pseudo-priority move in Prankster Copycat, Liepard separates itself from other Nasty Plot sweepers such as Skuntank and Alolan Persian. Copycat is mainly used to call Dark Pulse and prevent faster foes like Cinccino, Choice Scarf Rotom, and Basculin from revenge killing a Nasty Plot-boosted Liepard. Encore provides Liepard setup opportunities by locking foes such as Piloswine and Articuno into undesirable moves. Heavy-Duty Boots are preferred on VoltTurn teams to help Liepard avoid entry hazards and potentially pivot. Black Glasses are an alternative that makes up for Liepard's average Special Attack, making it require less chip damage to clean.

VoltTurn support from pivots such as Uxie, Articuno, and Rotom helps Liepard come on the field in spite of its lackluster bulk. Special wallbreakers such as Ninetales, Rotom, and Basculin can soften opposing special walls in order to let Liepard clean late game. Checks to Fighting-types such as Uxie, Qwilfish, and Rotom-S take on Sawk and Gurdurr, which force Liepard out. Likewise, checks to Fairy-types like Klinklang, Silvally-Poison, and Rapidash are great partners that handle Alcremie and Clefairy. Checks to Dark-types such as Alcremie, Gurdurr, and Sawk are also appreciated, as Silvally-Dark and Skuntank can take on Liepard. Kangaskhan is a threat because of Fake Out outprioritizing Copycat, letting it easily revenge kill a weakened Liepard; therefore, checks like Uxie, Tangela, and Cofagrigus are appreciated.

Gurdurr.comments:
Other Options

Defog is an option to turn Gurdurr into an entry hazard remover that poses good matchups against common entry hazard setters like Piloswine and Rhydon, but it generally has difficulty fitting the move. Stone Edge targets foes like Frosmoth, Rotom-S, and Articuno.

Checks and Counters

Flying-types: Although they do not appreciate Knock Off removing their Heavy-Duty Boots, Flying-types such as Rotom-S, Altaria, and Cramorant can threaten to KO Gurdurr.

Physical Walls: Physical walls such as Cofagrigus and Tangela are able to take hits from Gurdurr and pressure it with their STAB attacks. However, they should be wary of Knock Off. Alcremie is a notable foe that is able to take Gurdurr's STAB options and Knock Off and pressure it with its Fairy-type moves.

Chip Damage and Knock Off: It is easy to cripple and wear down Gurdurr, as it is reliant on Drain Punch recovery and Eviolite to check its foes.

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description:
Gurdurr is a notable tank in ZU thanks to its good bulk and access to decent recovery through Drain Punch. This recovery lets Gurdurr more consistently set up, letting it accumulate multiple boosts. Gurdurr can utilize Bulk Up mid- or late-game against passive foes like Stunfisk and Alolan Sandslash. Knock Off cripples switch-ins such as Tangela, Altaria, and Rotom-S. Mach Punch allows Gurdurr to revenge kill foes such as Shiftry and Cinccino. 252 HP and 60 Defense EVs ensure that Gurdurr will only be 3HKOed by Kangaskhan's Double-Edge, while 252 HP and 60 Special Defense EVs allow it to live Choice Specs Hydro Pump from Basculin after Stealth Rock damage. Guts lets Gurdurr absorb Will-O-Wisp from Rapidash and Toxic from Pyukumuku to empower its attacks.

Gurdurr fits on both bulky offense and balance teams due to its solid bulk and ability to generate pressure with both Bulk Up and Mach Punch. Gurdurr appreciates strong offensive support from its teammates to keep initiative throughout the battle, as it is otherwise prone to being worn down by common VoltTurn cores. Wallbreakers such as Rapidash, Silvally formes, and Thievul can threaten physical walls such as Cofagrigus, Tangela, and Qwilfish, enabling Gurdurr to better threaten them late-game. Pokemon such as Rotom and Frosmoth benefit from Gurdurr revenge killing foes such as Silvally-Dark and Shiftry with Mach Punch; in return, they can threaten Flying-types such as Rotom-S and Cramorant that trouble it.

Sawk.comments:
Other Options

Poison Jab lets Sawk 2HKO Alcremie and Clefairy, but this requires giving up one of its other coverage moves, which generally isn't preferred because they target more Pokemon.

Checks and Counters

Ghost-types: Cofagrigus, Spiritomb, and Sableye can switch into any of Sawk's attacks with ease. The former two can also set up on Sawk.

Physical Walls: Tangela, Uxie, and Altaria can switch into Sawk and either cripple it with their status moves or deal significant damage with their STAB moves. Tangela and Altaria must be careful of switching into Knock Off and Stone Edge, respectively, as Choice Band Sawk can 2HKO Tangela if it has lost its Eviolite and can KO Altaria with some prior chip damage. While Qwilfish must be wary of switching into Earthquake, it can easily switch into Close Combat and wear Sawk down with Rocky Helmet.

Faster Threats: Faster attackers such as Rotom, Basculin, and Cinccino can revenge kill Sawk if it has been slightly worn down. However, none of them can afford to risk directly switching into one of Sawk's attacks.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
With a solid Speed tier and its incredibly high attacking power, Sawk makes for an excellent revenge killer that fits well on offense and balance teams. Choice Scarf allows Sawk to threaten foes such as Alolan Persian, Kangaskhan, and non-Choice Scarf Cinccino. Knock Off targets Ghost- and Psychic-types such as Rotom, Gourgeist-S, and Uxie while also crippling common switch-ins such as Cofagrigus, Clefairy, and Tangela. Earthquake hits Poison-types such as Silvally-Poison, Qwilfish, and Skuntank. Stone Edge lets Sawk deal with Flying-types such as Rotom-S, Altaria, and Golbat. Mold Breaker allows Sawk to hit Levitate users such as Uxie and Rotom with Earthquake. Alternatively, Inner Focus allows Sawk to beat Qwilfish with Earthquake, as Inner Focus nullifies its Intimidate, and not flinch from Kangaskhan's Fake Out. However, don't expect to get free turns from Kangaskhan trying to flinch you, as the opponent should notice the absent Mold Breaker activation message.

While Sawk has super effective coverage for Pokemon that resist or are immune to Close Combat, it still needs physical walls such as Cofagrigus, Tangela, and Altaria to be weakened in order to KO them and successfully clean. Therefore, special attackers such as Skuntank, Rotom, and Basculin that can deal with them make for great partners. Entry hazard setters such as Alolan Sandslash, Piloswine, and Qwilfish help to wear down Sawk's common switch-ins, as most do not have access to reliable recovery. Pivots such as Uxie, Rotom-S, and Wishiwashi circumvent Sawk's mediocre bulk by safely bringing it onto the field, with the former also having access to Future Sight, which dissuades Poison-types from switching in.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Choice Band Sawk forgoes Choice Scarf's increase in Speed for more wallbreaking power, letting Close Combat net 2HKOs on neutral physical walls like Pyukumuku and Gurdurr. Knock Off pressures Ghost- and Psychic-types like Rotom and Uxie while also crippling common switch-ins such as Tangela; Close Combat threatens a 2HKO on Tangela once its Eviolite has been removed. Earthquake punishes Poison-types like Qwilfish and Silvally-Poison, while Stone Edge nails Flying-types such as Rotom-S and Altaria.

Choice Band Sawk is vulnerable to being revenge killed by faster Flying- and Psychic-types such as Rotom-S and Jynx, so switch-ins such as Rhydon and Articuno are appreciated. These Pokemon also have the added benefit of providing entry hazards to help wear down its switch-ins. Special setup sweepers such as Frosmoth and Alcremie benefit greatly from Sawk's ability to break past specially defensive walls such as Coalossal. Sawk also appreciates the removal of Ghost-types, so pairing it with Dark-types like Skuntank, Shiftry, and Alolan Persian is a good idea. Future Sight Uxie is a great partner, as it punishes the physical walls such as Tangela and Cofagrigus that switch in on Sawk and can also pivot Sawk in safely with U-turn. Sawk can also weaken the aforementioned walls into the KO range of physical cleaners like Rapidash and Swords Dance Silvally formes.

Basculin.comments:
Other Options

Surf is more accurate than Hydro Pump, but its lower power makes it less favorable than Hydro Pump. Mystic Water bluffs a Choice item and lures in foes like Ninetales and Altaria, allowing Basculin to potentially revenge kill them with Aqua Jet or Ice Beam. However, the extra power or Speed from Choice items are more beneficial. A physical Choice Scarf seems reasonable, but Hydro Pump's power makes special Choice Scarf sets better.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Water-types like Wishiwashi, Cramorant, and Poliwrath easily handle Basculin's STAB moves. However, they must be wary of Toxic. Qwilfish does a great job at tanking Basculin's physical attacks, but it cannot deal with Choice Specs sets.

Grass-types: Grass-types such as Tangela, Appletun, and Eldegoss can switch into Basculin's Water type attacks, but they must be careful of Ice Beam.

Faster Attackers: Faster foes like Cinccino and Manectric are able to revenge kill Basculin, but they have to watch out for Choice Scarf Basculin or Aqua Jet.

Priority Users: Priority users such as Thwackey and Kangaskhan easily remove Basculin due to its poor bulk.

Special Walls: Articuno and Clefairy handle Choice Specs Basculin well, but all of these Pokemon have to watch out for Choice Band Basculin.

Altaria: Altaria can endure physical attacks, take most special attacks, and can switch out to remove Toxic. However, it has to watch out for Ice Beam from special sets.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
As a result of deadly Adaptability-boosted STAB moves, great Speed tier, and unpredictability between special and physical sets, Basculin is a premier special wallbreaker. However, it's incredibly frail, so it has to be cautious of revenge killers like Kangaskhan, Cinccino, and Gourgeist-S. Flip Turn allows Basculin to chip switch-ins and checks like Cramorant and Wishiwashi while keeping momentum. Ice Beam deals with some Water-resistant foes like Tangela and Altaria. Toxic cripples foes like Cramorant and Wishiwashi.

Basculin typically fits on offensive and balance teams looking for an immediate special wallbreaker with a solid Speed tier. Choice Specs Basculin provides great support for physical wallbreakers like Kangaskhan and Sawk that have trouble with physical walls. In return, they can deal with special walls like Wishiwashi and Clefairy, which Basculin struggles to break through. Defensive pivots such as Uxie and Articuno can take hits for Basculin and bring it safely on the field with U-turn, while Basculin helps them with its pivoting. This works very well in tandem with entry hazard support from the likes of Coalossal and Alolan Sandslash, as it allows Basculin to OHKO targets like Cofagrigus and Gurdurr. Partners like Ninetales and Frosmoth cover Grass-types like Tangela, while teammates like Thwackey and Rotom handle Water-types like Wishiwashi and Cramorant.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Choice Band Basculin takes advantage of its respectable Speed tier and Adaptability to tear through Pokemon that normally absorb its special attacks, like Clefairy and Articuno. Flip Turn chips checks such as Altaria and Cramorant while keeping momentum. Aqua Jet helps Basculin revenge kill weakened, faster foes such as Cinccino and Ninetales. Psychic Fangs can be used to provide coverage against Qwilfish and Poliwrath, which can similarly handle the rest of Basculin's attacks well.

Basculin pairs well with special attackers such as Alcremie, Frosmoth, Ninetales, and Rotom, as it can take down special walls like Articuno and Clefairy that its teammates struggle with and also lure in physical walls and use Flip Turn. Defensive pivots like Uxie, Alolan Persian, and Articuno let Basculin safely enter the field and can take hits for it. Offensive pivots such as Rotom and Cinccino similarly allow Basculin to safely enter the field by threatening or KOing foes. Basculin pairs nicely with Pokemon that can threaten Water-types such as Rotom, Thwackey, and Manectric. Frosmoth, Rapidash, and Ninetales take care of Grass-types, with Frosmoth notably also checking one of the biggest threats to Basculin in Altaria.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Choice Scarf Basculin is a great choice for teams that want a very hard hitting revenge killer and pivot. Flip Turn chips switch-ins such as Cramorant and Clefairy while providing momentum. Ice Beam is great coverage against Pokemon like Altaria and Tangela, which can normally switch into its Water-type attacks. Toxic cripples checks like Cramorant and Wishiwashi.

Choice Scarf Basculin is usually found on offense and balance teams looking for a revenge killer. VoltTurn cores love having Basculin on their team, as it enables these cores with Flip Turn while bulkier pivots like Alolan Persian and Uxie can help Basculin switch in easily. Teammates such as Articuno and Skuntank serve as answers to bulky Grass-types like Tangela and Appletun. Thwackey and Rotom check Water-types that sponge Basculin's attacks and are additional offensive pivots that keep momentum. Lastly, entry hazard removers like Altaria and Rotom-S clear entry hazards that wear down Basculin as it pivots.

Cinccino.comments:
Other Options

King's Rock synergizes well with Skill Link and multi-hit moves, giving Cinccino's attacks a whopping 41% chance to make its targets flinch. Heavy-Duty Boots prevents Cinccino from being worn down by entry hazards. Protective Pads can prevent Cinccino from being worn down from residual damage such as Rocky Helmet and Iron Barbs. However, forgoing Choice Band for one of the aforementioned items results in a noticeable loss of power.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-types: Fighting-types such as Sawk and Gurdurr are problematic for Cinccino. Choice Scarf Sawk outspeeds and can OHKO it, while Gurdurr can revenge kill Cinccino with Mach Punch.

Ghost-types: Although they do not appreciate Knock Off, Ghost-types such as Cofagrigus and Rotom check Cinccino by switching into Tail Slap. Both Cofagrigus and Rotom can cripple Cinccino with Will-O-Wisp, and Cofagrigus is also able to OHKO Cinccino with Body Press.

Residual Damage: Residual damage from Iron Barbs and Rocky Helmet can severely weaken Cinccino, as each Tail Slap hit connecting results in it being damaged five times. Entry hazards prevent Cinccino from repeatedly switching into battle and can put it in range of a potential revenge killer.

Steel-types: Steel-types such as Alolan Sandslash and Perrserker are able to handle Tail Slap. However, they should be wary of being weakened by Knock Off and U-turn.

Revenge Killers: Although Cinccino is relatively fast, its mediocre bulk means that Pokemon like Alolan Persian and Choice Scarf users like Basculin and Poliwrath can revenge kill it easily. Similarly, strong priority users like Kangaskhan and Shiftry can also threaten Cinccino.

sets.name: All-out Attacker
sets.description:
The combination of Skill Link + Tail Slap makes Cinccino a notable offensive threat that is able to revenge kill a majority of the ZU metagame. Bullet Seed provides coverage against Rock-types such as Kabutops and Rhydon that resist Tail Slap. Knock Off weakens Ghost-types such as Cofagrigus, Gourgeist-Small, and Rotom and cripples Eviolite-reliant Pokemon such as Rhydon and Tangela. U-turn is useful for establishing and retaining momentum against the aforementioned Rock-, Steel-, and Ghost-types, while Rock Blast can be used to OHKO Coalossal and Rapidash without activating Flame Body.

Fighting-types such as Sawk and Gurdurr complement Cinccino by pressuring problematic Steel- and Rock-types such as Alolan Sandslash and Rhydon, easing Cinccino's ability to break through them. Ghost-type checks such as Rotom and Silvally-Dark are also appreciated, handling foes such as Cofagrigus and Gourgeist-Small; in return, Cinccino can form a VoltTurn core with them and safely pivot them into battle. Special wallbreakers such as Choice Specs Basculin and Thievul also appreciate U-turn support, and they can threaten physical walls that switch into Cinccino. Entry hazard removal from the likes of Cramorant and the aforementioned Rotom can alleviate Cinccino's susceptibility to entry hazards from its frequent pivoting.

Cryogonal.comments:
Other Options

Rapid Spin can be used over Defog on entry hazard stacking teams to avoid removing Cryogonal's own entry hazards. Haze is also useful against special setup sweepers such as Frosmoth and Rotom-F. A dual screens set with Reflect, Light Screen, and Explosion has a niche on hyper offense teams.

Checks and Counters

Physical Attackers: Physical attackers such as Kangaskhan, Rhydon, and Silvally formes threaten Cryogonal due to its low physical bulk.

Fighting-types: Fighting-types such as Gurdurr and Sawk can threaten to OHKO Cryogonal. Specifically, Choice Scarf Sawk outspeeds Cryogonal and OHKOes it, while Gurdurr easily tanks Freeze-Dry and threatens Cryogonal with Drain Punch.

Fire-types: Fire-types such as Ninetales and Rapidash resist Freeze-Dry and force Cryogonal out.

Steel-types: Ferroseed and Perrserker tank Freeze-Dry and can retaliate with their STAB attacks. Offensive Steel-types like Alolan Dugtrio and Klinklang force Cryogonal out. However, they do not appreciate taking a Knock Off.

Item Removal: Knock Off users such as Uxie, Clefairy, Alolan Persian, and Audino and Trick users like Rotom can threaten to cripple Cryogonal by removing its Heavy-Duty Boots, which makes it vulnerable to Stealth Rock and lowers its ability to switch in.

sets.name: Special Wall
sets.description:
Cryogonal is a fast, niche Defogger in the metagame that has great special bulk and can offensively pressure Qwilifsh. Cryogonal also performs well as a specially defensive wall, checking prevalent special attackers such as Articuno, Rotom formes, and Frosmoth. It has access to reliable recovery in Recover and great utility with the combination of Toxic and Knock Off.

Nonetheless, Cryogonal's low Defense stat and poor defensive typing make it vulnerable to a majority of physical attackers. Altaria can help Cryogonal check both Fire- and Fighting-type moves. Tangela can also check physical attackers such as Sawk, Cinccino, and Gurdurr, which force out Cryogonal. In return, Cryogonal counters special attackers such as Choice Specs Basculin and Frosmoth. On balance builds, Fire-types like Ninetales and Rapidash is a great partner for Cryogonal, handling Ferroseed; in return, Cryogonal is able to pressure its checks such as Altaria and bulky Water-types like Wishiwashi. Water-types like Qwilfish, Poliwrath, and Jellicent help check Fire-types such as Rapidash and Ninetales, which annoy Cryogonal. Bulky Fighting-types such as Gurdurr and Throh also pair well with Cryogonal, checking Ferroseed and threatening Steel-types.

Stunfisk.comments:
Other Options

Rest provides Stunfisk with recovery and lets it remove status, but it makes Stunfisk even more passive. Stone Edge or Rock Slide is an option to directly threaten Articuno and Frosmoth. Thunder Wave provides a more reliable method of slowing foes like Sawk and Silvally formes, while Protect synergizes with Toxic and Leftovers, wearing down foes and providing Stunfisk with more recovery. However, Stunfisk often has difficulty fitting either move.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Grass-types like Tangela, Thwackey, and Eldegoss threaten Stunfisk with their attacks or status and force it out. However, they do not appreciate Toxic.

Water-types: Although they cannot directly switch into Discharge or Toxic, Water-types like Basculin, Poliwrath, and Wishiwashi can effectively handle Stunfisk.

Ice-types: Despite its great special bulk, Stunfisk is vulnerable to powerful Ice-types like Frosmoth, Aurorus, and Jynx.

Ground-types: Ground-types like Rhydon and Piloswine target Stunfisk's lack of reliable recovery and heavily damage or KO it with their strong attacks.

Strong Physical Attackers: Strong physical attackers like Cinccino, Kangaskhan, and Sawk heavily pressure Stunfisk with their attacks, although they dislike Static.

Residual Damage: Stunfisk's lack of reliable recovery leaves it vulnerable to Spikes and Toxic from foes such as Qwilfish, Rapidash, and Clefairy.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description:
Stunfisk is a notable specially defensive wall and Stealth Rock setter in ZU that has good matchups against common threats like Rotom, Skuntank, and Manectric. Toxic wears down switch-ins like Tangela, Rhydon, and Piloswine and Defoggers like Articuno and Rotom formes. Earth Power prevents Stunfisk from being passive against prominent special attackers like Manectric, Skuntank, and Ninetales. Discharge allows Stunfisk to spread paralysis and deal with most Defoggers, while Foul Play lets it handle Substitute + Nasty Plot Rotom and physical setup sweepers like Thwackey, which may try to take advantage of Stunfisk to safely set up. Static punishes physical attackers like Kangaskhan, Cinccino, and Alolan Persian, and it can also give Stunfisk a chance to cripple checks like physical Basculin and Thwackey in an emergency situation.
