Stunfisk fits primarily on balance and bulky offense teams and provides valuable role compression. Grass-types like Tangela, Thwackey, and Gourgeist-S handle Water- and Ground-types like Wishiwashi and Rhydon; in return, Stunfisk can take on Poison-types like Silvally-Poison and Skuntank for them. Fire-types like Rapidash and Ninetales pressure the aforementioned Grass-types, as well as Ice-types like Articuno and Frosmoth, for Stunfisk. As Stunfisk has a poor matchup against other Stealth Rock setters like Rhydon and Piloswine, it is adviseable to pair it with Water-types like Poliwrath, Basculin, and Cramorant; Cramorant is a notable partner that can provide Defog and check powerful foes like Sawk while benefitting greatly from Stunfisk dealing with Electric-types. Toxic absorbers like Altaria and Qwilfish prevent Stunfisk from getting worn down; a Toxic Spikes absorber like Silvally-Poison or Qwilfish is likewise helpful. Cleric support from partners like Clefairy and Alcremie helps Stunfisk remain healthy, especially on bulkier teams.

Stunfisk-Galar.comments:
Other Options

Snap Trap traps and chips down targets while synergizing with Yawn to inflict foes with sleep. However, having one of these moves reduces Galarian Stunfisk's coverage and utility in other areas and leaves it unable to deal with Substitute + Nasty Plot Rotom formes; they should only been used in specific situations. Thunder Wave cripples and forces out faster foes like Kangaskhan and Silvally formes; however, it leaves Stunfisk Galarian unable to punish Ground-types. Protect allows Galarian Stunfisk to gain more recovery from Leftovers and lets it scout Choice item users such as Sawk and Rotom. Rest is also used as a recovery option, but it is considerably niche and only fits on select teams. Rest is best used when paired with Heal Bell support from Articuno, Clefairy, or Altaria on stall teams.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Water-types such as Basculin, Cramorant, and Wishiwashi handle Galarian Stunfisk with their super effective STAB moves.

Ground-types: Ground-types such as Rhydon, Piloswine, and Silvally-Gound force out Galarian Stunfisk out, with the former two using that opportunity to set up Stealth Rock and the latter setting up with Swords Dance.

Fighting-type Pokemon and Coverage: Fighting-types such as Sawk and Gurdurr threaten Galarian Stunfisk with their super effective STAB moves, while Cofagrigus can set up with Iron Defense and KO it with Body Press.

Fire-types: Fire-types such as Ninetales and Rapidash threaten Galarian Stunfisk, although they cannot safely switch in due to Galarian Stunfisk's Rock / Ground coverage.

Strong Wallbreakers: While Galarian Stunfisk does have great bulk, it can easily get overwhelmed by strong setup sweepers such as Swords Dance Shiftry, Silvally-Ground, and Iron Defense Cofagrigus.

Item Removal: Pokemon such as Knock Off Uxie and Trick Rotom can remove Galarian Stunfisk's main form of recovery in Leftovers, limiting its effectiveness as a special wall.

Spikes: Spikes chips down Galarian Stunfisk over time, limiting its switch-ins and effectiveness as a special wall.

sets.name: Special Wall
sets.description:
Galarian Stunfisk is a great Stealth Rock setter in the metagame thanks to its high HP stat, solid defensive stats, and great defensive typing that lets it wall threats such as Rotom formes and Frosmoth. Rock Slide hits Pokemon such as Cramorant, Articuno, Frosmoth, and the aforementioned Rotom formes; Rock Slide is more consistent than Stone Edge and preferred due to its higher accuracy and PP. Curse turns Galarian Stunfisk into a threatening late-game cleaner while also making up for its passivity. Yawn forces switches from Pokemon that wall Galarian Stunfisk, such as Uxie and Tangela. Foul Play deals significant damage to Swords Dance users such as Silvally formes.

Galarian Stunfisk is a decent pick on balance and stall teams thanks to it compressing the role of an Electric immunity, Stealth Rock setter, and special wall. Bulky Water-types such as Cramorant and Wishiwashi are great partners to Galarian Stunfisk, as they can take on Water-types such as Basculin and Poliwrath, which threaten Galarian Stunfisk, while also benefitting from Galarian Stunfisk's Electric immunity. Grass-types are also great partners to cover Galarian Stunfisk's weaknesses, with Appletun covering its weaknesses to Ground, Water, and Fire, while Gourgeist-S and Trevenant cover its weaknesses to Ground, Water, and Fighting. Uxie can also work as a partner, as it is resistant to Fighting and immune to Ground. Spikes stacking teams also appreciate Galarian Stunfisk's ability to force switches with Yawn, with a Spikes setter such as Qwilfish also covering Galarian Stunfisk's weakness to Fighting.

Wishiwashi.comments:
Other Options

Wishiwashi can opt for a physically defensive spread of 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 SpD with a Bold or Impish nature to better handle physical attackers such as Rhydon and Rapidash at the cost of losing the ability to reliably check special attackers such as Ninetales.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Offensive Grass-types such as Flapple and Gourgeist-S are able to OHKO Wishiwashi, while Thwackey and Shiftry can KO Wishiwashi with a bit of prior chip. However, these Pokemon, particularly Shiftry, must be careful of switching into U-turn. Defensive Grass-types such as Appletun and Tangela can deal with Wishiwashi and do not take much from its attacks, but they must be wary of Toxic.

Electric-types: The Rotom formes and Manectric threaten Wishiwashi out with their STAB attacks, with the former also being able to cripple it with Trick.

Residual Damage: Entry hazards limit the number of times Wishiwashi can safely switch in and wear it down to Solo Form much faster. Altaria, Articuno, and Clefairy can also cripple non-RestTalk Wishiwashi variants with Toxic.

Knock Off: Wishiwashi is reliant on Leftovers as its means of recovery, so Knock Off users such as Gurdurr, Alolan Persian, and Clefairy can reduce Wishiwashi's longevity.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description:
With access to a slow U-turn and naturally high defenses, Wishiwashi makes for an excellent slow pivot and mixed wall, checking the likes of Rapidash and Basculin. Scald can burn physical attackers such as Gourgeist-S and Flapple that attempt to switch in, while Liquidation is a guaranteed OHKO on Fire-types such as Ninetales. Toxic cripples bulkier foes like Appletun and Tangela, as well as dissuading setup sweepers like Frosmoth and Swoobat from switching in. Protect synergizes well with Toxic and lets Wishiwashi scout attacks from Choiced-locked Pokemon such as Rotom, Cinccino, and Sawk. Additionally, Protect lets Wishiwashi acquire more Leftovers recovery, which is essential for staying above Schooling's deactivation threshold. Alternatively, Wishiwashi can give up some utility and opt for Rest for some much needed instant recovery. Sleep Talk should be used in conjunction with Rest in order to avoid being overly passive when asleep. Rest Wishiwashi is also a great status absorber, making it a more reliable pivot against stall teams.

The best use of Wishiwashi's slow U-turn is to pair it with offensive threats such as Sawk, Kangaskhan, and Shiftry that typically struggle to switch into attacks. Pivots such as the Rotom formes and Uxie make for great Wishiwashi partners, as they can form a VoltTurn core to keep momentum while wearing down foes. Wishiwashi's lack of reliable recovery means it is very vulnerable to being worn down by entry hazards; Defog users such as Rotom-S and Articuno help to alleviate this issue. Ground-types like Rhydon and Piloswine appreciate Wishiwashi's slow U-turn, and in return, they can deal with Electric-types such as Rotom, Rotom-S, and Morepeko. Grass-resistant Pokemon such as Ninetales and Skuntank are good Pokemon to pair with Wishiwashi, as they can switch into Pokemon like Shiftry, Thwackey, and Gourgeist-S that threaten Wishiwashi out.

Type: Null.comments:
Other Options

A set with Iron Defense / Swords Dance / Crush Claw / Rest and an EV spread of 248 HP / 8 Def / 252 SpD is sometimes used to turn Type: Null into an unbreakable and powerful sweeper. However, this set is not consistent due to it only having Normal-type coverage and is walled by the common Ghost-types in the tier; in addition, it is passive thanks to the lack of Sleep Talk. This set also lacks the utility of the pivot set, and Type: Null also needs multiple boosts to become threatening due to its low Attack stat.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-type Pokemon and Coverage: Type: Null is weak to Fighting, so it should be careful of Pokemon like Sawk, Gurdurr, and Poliwrath, as well as Fighting-type coverage such as Body Press from Cofagrigus.

Strong Physical Wallbreakers: Strong physical wallbreakers such as Sawk and Swords Dance Silvally formes can muscle their way through Type: Null.

Knock Off: Any Pokemon with Knock Off is a threat, as losing Eviolite significantly decreases Type: Null's bulk.

Taunt: Taunt users such as Skuntank and Qwilfish stop Type: Null from recovering and spreading status, forcing it to pivot.

Setup Sweepers that Bypass Toxic: Setup sweepers with Substitute such as Rotom formes can freely set up in front of Type: Null. Poison- and Steel-types such as Skuntank and Klinklang, as well as Pokemon that can cure status like Rest Cofagrigus and Aromatherapy Alcremie, can also set up for free.

Entry Hazards: Although Type: Null is not weak to Stealth Rock, its lack of passive recovery and constant pivoting cause it to get easily chipped down, limiting the amount of times it can switch in and lowering its usefulness as a wall.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description:
Type: Null acts as a niche defensive pivot in the metagame thanks to its sizable bulk with Eviolite and access to U-turn. This bulk allows it to check top-tier special wallbreakers such as Basculin, Ninetales, and Thievul. Type: Null's slow U-turn allows it to pivot and safely bring in a teammate. Toxic cripples foes and prevents Pokemon such as Cofagrigus, Rapidash, and Silvally formes from freely setting up in front of it. RestTalk is Type: Null's only form of recovery and lets it consistently pivot. A Sassy nature and 0 Speed IVs minimize Type: Null's Speed, allowing for the slowest U-turns.

Type: Null is a great pick for teams looking for a pivot, special wall, and status absorber condensed into one Pokemon. It pairs well with other pivots, forming a VoltTurn core. Uxie is an excellent pivot to pair with Type: Null, as it benefits from Type: Null's immunity to Ghost and ability to sponge strong special hits; in return, Uxie is able to switch into strong Fighting-types such as Sawk and Gurdurr that trouble Type: Null. Wallbreakers such as Thievul, Basculin, and Arctovish appreciate Type: Null's slow U-turn safely bringing them in. Although Type: Null can sponge special wallbreakers, it cannot do much damage back and is heavily dependent on pivoting into revenge killers to adequately check special sweepers. Thus, priority users like Kangaskhan and Gurdurr are necessary when dealing with foes such as Shiftry and Frosmoth. Finally, Knock Off absorbers such as Qwilfish and Silvally formes work as partners, as they prevent Type: Null from losing its Eviolite.

Silvally-Dark.comments:
Other Options

X-Scissor is an option over U-turn for a stronger move to threaten opposing Dark-types. Toxic can be used to cripple physical walls such as Tangela and Pyukumuku, but it makes Silvally-Dark less effective at wallbreaking. Defog provides role compression, and it is a niche option on certain teams.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Although they do not appreciate U-turn, Dark-types such as Alolan Persian and Skuntank can take Multi-Attack from Silvally-Dark and threaten it back with status or a powerful hit.

Fighting-types: Fighting-types such as Sawk, Poliwrath, and Gurdurr are able to take Multi-Attack and pressure back with their STAB moves. Gurdurr can also revenge kill Silvally-Dark with Mach Punch, even after it has set up; Choice Scarf Sawk can similarly revenge kill it due to outspeeding it. However, all Fighting-types should be wary of +2 Psychic Fangs.

Fairy-types: Fairy-types such as Alcremie, Clefairy, and Carbink can threaten Silvally-Dark with their STAB options, but they have to watch out for Iron Head variants.

Revenge Killers: Faster attackers such as Basculin, Rapidash, and Cinccino can outspeed and threaten Silvally-Dark. Pokemon with priority moves such as Kangaskhan and Thwackey can similarly KO it once it has been weakened.

sets.name: Swords Dance Sweeper
sets.description:
Silvally-Dark finds a niche in ZU as a powerful setup sweeper, capable of setting up with Swords Dance and utilizing its Multi-Attack to threaten prominent Pokemon such as Uxie, Spiritomb, and Rotom. However, it faces competition from other Silvally formes. U-turn allows Silvally-Dark to function as an early-game pivot and lets it weaken Dark-types such as Alolan Persian and Skuntank, while Flame Charge allows it to outspeed revenge killers such as Choice Scarf Sawk and Basculin. Psychic Fangs can be used to threaten Fighting-types such as Poliwrath and Sawk, while Iron Head weakens Fairy-types such as Alcremie and Clefairy.

Silvally-Dark fits best on offensive teams as an early-game pivot that can wallbreak with its powerful Multi-Attack. If running Flame Charge, Silvally-Dark should be preserved for late-game, when it can set up with both Swords Dance and Flame Charge and sweep. Silvally-Dark has trouble with Dark-types such as Alolan Persian and Skuntank, so checks to them such as Alcremie and Piloswine, respectively, are appreciated. Checks to Fighting-types such as Rotom-S, Qwilfish, and the aforementioned Alcremie are also appreciated, with Rotom-S forming a VoltTurn core with Silvally-Dark and Qwilfish providing Spikes support, weakening foes such as Qwilfish into the range of +2 Multi-Attack. Magneton is a noteworthy partner, benefitting from Silvally-Dark luring in Fairy-types and physical walls such as Tangela and Poliwrath for it to threaten. As Silvally-Dark lacks recovery, entry hazard removal from the likes of Rotom-S and Cramorant is necessary to keep Silvally-Dark healthy to keep pivoting with U-turn. Dual screens support from Uxie can help Silvally-Dark more easily set up with both Swords Dance and Flame Charge and let it avoid being revenge killed by Kangaskhan.

Thievul.comments:
Other Options

Thievul can be ran on Electric Terrain teams with Electric Seed, although the archetype isn't very effective. Thievul can use the combination of Throat Spray + Snarl or Sitrus Berry + Substitute to activate Unburden; however, these sets need several turns to set up and are often not worth using. Hyper Beam is Thievul's strongest move and an option on both sets to nuke Dark- and Fairy-types such as Silvally-Dark and Alcremie, but it is exploitable and gives the foe a free turn, and Thievul can outspeed and 2HKO most of these threats with its other moves. A Timid nature can be used on the Choice Specs set to give Thievul a better matchup against more offensive teams; however, a Modest nature lets Thievul break through special walls like Throh, Eviolite-less Clefairy, and Wishiwashi with a boost from Stakeout.

Checks and Counters

Fairy-types: Thanks to their great special bulk and resistance to Thievul's STAB moves, Fairy-types such as Carbink, Alcremie, and Clefairy easily wall Thievul, even if non-specially defensive variants of them have to watch out for Stakeout-boosted Psychic.

Dark-types: Dark-types such as Skuntank, Silvally-Dark, and Shiftry tank Dark Pulse and Psychic and threaten Thievul. However, they aren't extremely reliable, as they still take heavy damage from Stakeout-boosted moves and Nasty Plot-boosted Burning Jealousy.

Fighting-types: Without a Stakeout or Nasty Plot boost, Thievul fails to OHKO Fighting-types such as Poliwrath, Gurdurr, and Throh, which can take it out.

Faster Attackers: Due to its mediocre bulk, Choice Specs Thievul is forced out by faster attackers such as Silvally formes, Sawk, and Kangaskhan.

Specially Defensive Walls: Without a Stakeout or Nasty Plot boost, specially defensive walls such as Articuno and Wishiwashi can easily wall Thievul. However, Thievul can 2HKO them with its Stakeout- or Nasty Plot-boosted moves, so they have to be played carefully.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Thievul is a deadly wallbreaker thanks to the combination of Choice Specs and Stakeout. Psychic OHKOes Fighting-types such as Sawk, Gurdurr, and Poliwrath with a Stakeout boost and serves as its strongest move for Fairy-types such as Alcremie and Clefairy. Despite its low base power, Burning Jealousy is Thievul's strongest option for Dark-types such as Skuntank, Shiftry, and Alolan Persian and lets Thievul force out some special walls like Frosmoth and Alolan Sandslash. Knock Off is an alternative that cripples Eviolite-reliant walls such as Clefairy and Type: Null, letting Thievul beat them later with its other moves.

Thievul works best on offensive teams looking for a very powerful special wallbreaker. Physical wallbreakers such as Basculin, Rapidash, and Silvally formes can force in physical walls such as Qwilfish, Tangela, and Uxie, giving Thievul an opportunity to switch in. These partners can also break through specially defensive Pokemon that give Thievul a hard time, such as Clefairy, Articuno, and Alcremie. Since Fairy-, Dark-, and Fighting-types such as Clefairy, Silvally-Dark, and Sawk threaten Thievul, checks to these types, such as Rapidash, Gurdurr, and Rotom-S, are appreciated. VoltTurn users such as Wishiwashi, Uxie, and Rotom-S create opportunities for Thievul to activate Stakeout. Due to Thievul's average Speed tier, it struggles versus more offensive teams; therefore, fast Pokemon such as Cinccino and Choice Scarf Sawk make for great partners.

Coalossal.comments:
Other Options

Will-O-Wisp allows Coalossal to consistently cripple opposing physical attackers, but it generally has difficulty fitting the move. Overheat is an alternative over Flamethrower, but its low PP and Special Attack drop make it less desirable than Flamethrower. Heat Crash is also a notable alternative, but Coalossal has trouble breaking Tangela with it. Similarly, Stone Edge can be used over Rock Blast, but its low PP and inaccuracy can be exploited by foes like Articuno.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Coalossal's 4x weakness to Water causes it to be threatened by the plethora of Water-types in ZU, such as Basculin, Qwilfish, and Wishiwashi. However, physical Water-types should be wary of being burned by Flame Body.

Ground-type Pokemon and Coverage: Ground-types such as Piloswine, Rhydon, and Galarian Stunfisk are able to exploit Coalossal's 4x weakness to Ground and threaten it with Earthquake, which avoids Flame Body, or set up entry hazards. Physical attackers such as Kangaskhan and Sawk can OHKO Coalossal with Earthquake and not activate Flame Body. Opposing Fire-types like Ninetales and Rapidash often carry Ground-type coverage moves to threaten Coalossal.

Fighting-types: Fighting-types like Sawk, Gurdurr, and Poliwrath can threaten Coalossal with their STAB options, although they dislike being burned.

Knock Off: Coalossal heavily relies on Heavy-Duty Boots to consistently switch in and remove entry hazards. Losing it, combined with its lack of recovery, allows it to get easily worn down.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description:
Coalossal finds a distinct niche in ZU as a Spikes setter that provides good defensive utility against common foes such as Frosmoth, Articuno, and Rotom. It can force the aforementioned foes out to set up Spikes or remove entry hazards with Rapid Spin. Stealth Rock can be used if Coalossal is not paired with a Stealth Rock setter or if there is already a Rapid Spin user on the team. Rock Blast allows Coalossal to threaten Substitute users such as Frosmoth and Articuno and entry hazard removers such as Rotom-S and Altaria. Flamethrower lets Coalossal force out Tangela and Alolan Sandslash, giving it the opportunity to reliably use Rapid Spin. Flame Body deters physical attackers like Cinccino and Silvally from spamming their STAB moves, and it can potentially cripple threats such as Sawk and physical Basculin in an emergency situation.

Coalossal can provide both entry hazard setting and removal for certain bulky offense teams. As Coalossal has 4x weaknesses to both Water and Ground, it is recommended to pair Coalossal with Grass-types such as Tangela and Thwackey. Tangela is also able to tank hits from Fighting-types such as Sawk and Poliwrath, while Thwackey is able to provide passive recovery and reduce damage from Earthquake. Knock Off absorbers such as Uxie and Alolan Persian can preserve Coalossal's Heavy-Duty Boots, letting it consistently pivot in to remove entry hazards; Uxie can also threaten the aforementioned Fighting-types.

Flapple.comments:
Other Options

An Adamant nature gives Flapple additional breaking power but leaves it outpaced by the likes of Frosmoth. A Choice Scarf set with a Jolly nature outpaces threats like Cinccino and Basculin, but it is still notably outpaced by Accelgor, faster Choice Scarf users like Sawk, and setup sweepers like +1 Silvally formes.

Checks and Counters

Faster Pokemon: While they can't switch-in directly, faster Pokemon like Rotom-S, Accelgor, and Skuntank are able to outspeed and OHKO Flapple due to its poor bulk and defensive typing.

Ice-type Moves: Flapple's 4x weakness to Ice leaves it easily disposed of by faster Ice-types such as Articuno and Cryogonal, while Piloswine is able to OHKO Flapple with its priority Ice Shard. This weakness also leaves it susceptible to Ice-type coverage such as Basculin's Ice Beam.

Steel-types: Steel-types such as Alolan Sandslash and Perrserker resist both of Flapple's STAB moves.

Fairy-types: While Fairy-types such as Alcremie and Clefairy are unable to switch into Grav Apple, they can take advantage of Flapple if it locks itself into Outrage or Sucker Punch.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Flapple is a devastating wallbreaker thanks to its solid offensive typing in tandem with its Hustle-boosted attacks, allowing it to dismantle defensive cores consisting of Pokemon like Cofagrigus, Pyukumuku, and Altaria. Grav Apple is Flapple's primary STAB move, with its Defense drop punishing switch-ins, reducing Flapple's reliance on prediction. A mixed Life Orb set with Draco Meteor allows Flapple to bypass Grass-resistant Pokemon and physical walls such as Altaria, Qwilfish, and Tangela. On the the other hand, a Choice Band set with Outrage handles specially bulky Grass-resistant Pokemon like Articuno and Frosmoth. Sucker Punch OHKOes faster offensive threats such as Choice Scarf Rotom as well as picking off Accelgor and Cinccino after some chip damage. Alternatively, Grassy Glide can be used on Grassy Terrain teams, threatening all faster Pokemon that do not resist Grass. Hustle does allow Flapple to 2HKO just about any Pokemon in the metagame, but its accuracy drop, combined with Flapple relying on a drawback-laden Draco Meteor or Outrage to dispatch Grass-resistant Pokemon such as Altaria, makes Flapple somewhat unreliable.

Flapple's poor bulk and defensive typing give it few direct switch-in opportunities, so it pairs well with bulky pivots that are able to bring it in safely such as Uxie, Wishiwashi, and Rotom-S. Alolan Sandslash and Qwilfish provide Flapple entry hazard support as well as pressuring Fairy-types like Alcremie and Clefairy. Special attackers such as Cramorant and Rotom appreciate Flapple's ability to pressure special walls like Wishiwashi and Stunfisk. In return, Cramorant provides entry hazard removal, while Rotom forms an effective VoltTurn core with Flapple. Ninetales and Rapidash easily handle Ice- and Steel-types like Articuno, Klinklang, and Alolan Sandslash that Flapple struggles with, while Flapple can break down their checks such as Altaria and Wishiwashi. Late-game cleaners such as Choice Scarf Sawk and Silvally formes appreciate Flapple's ability to break walls such as Cofagrigus and Pyukumuku, respectively. Flapple works well on Grassy Terrain teams, supporting its teammates by threatening conventional Grass-type checks like Altaria.

Cramorant.comments:
Other Options

Hurricane is an alternative to Brave Bird that is weaker against Frosmoth, but stronger against physically bulky Pokemon such as Poliwrath and Qwilfish. Substitute synergizes well with Gulp Missile, helping Cramorant reach the range for its Gorging forme; however, it is generally less effective than Cramorant's other moves. An offensive spread of 4 Def / 252 SpA / 252 Spe can be utilized with Hurricane to better offensively pressure foes such as Tangela and Gurdurr.

Checks and Counters

Electric-types: Electric-types like Rotom and Rotom-S can OHKO Cramorant.

Strong Attackers: Although they dislike taking damage and a potential paralysis from Gulp Missile, strong attackers such as Silvally-Dark and Kangaskhan are capable of easily KOing Cramorant.

Toxic: Toxic from foes like Wishiwashi and Miltank, as residual damage does not activate Gulp Missile.

sets.name: Defog
sets.description:
Cramorant finds a niche in ZU as a Defogger, threatening common entry hazard setters such as Rhydon and Piloswine. Roost is necessary to improve Cramorant's longevity and lets it consistently switch into the likes of Accelgor and Poliwrath. Surf activates Gulp Missile, allowing Cramorant to punish attackers, and can potentially paralyze them if Gulp Missile is activated when it has no more than 50% HP. Brave Bird complements Surf by weakening foes such as Qwilifish and Wishiwashi while ignoring Ice Scales from Frosmoth, letting Cramorant OHKO it; Brave Bird also benefits from Gulp Missile lowering the foe's Defense stat when Cramorant is above 50% HP.

Although Cramorant is an effective Defogger, its 4x weakness to Electric makes it susceptible to Rotom formes. Checks to them such as Rhydon and Piloswine are appreciated; Rhydon can also check Kangaskhan. Knock Off absorbers like Silvally formes and Alolan Persian can improve Cramorant's longevity and let it consistently clear entry hazards by keeping Heavy-Duty Boots intact; in return, the former two appreciate Cramorant checking Frosmoth and the latter values it threatening opposing Ground-types. Cramorant's ability to inflict paralysis with Gulp Missile at low HP complements slow wallbreakers like Arctovish and Skuntank and aids them against fast attackers like Cinccino and Sawk. Powerful attackers such as Silk Scarf Kangaskhan, Silvally formes, and Cinccino appreciate Cramorant's Defog letting them consistently switch into battle.

Hattrem.comments:
Other Options

Hattrem has a very wide movepool with options like Aromatherapy, and Calm Mind. However, getting rid off one of the standard moves comes with a lot of opportunity cost and is not advisable.

Checks and Counters

Item Removal: Hattrem relies on its Eviolite to reliably wall entry hazard setters such as defensive Rhydon and Alolan Sandslash and should avoid getting crippled by Knock Off users such as Gurdurr and Sawk.

Offensive Entry Hazard Setters: Foes such as Accelgor and offensive Rhydon easily muscle through Hattrem and can set up entry hazards against it.

Dark-, Ghost-, and Bug-type Pokemon and Coverage: Pokemon such as Shiftry, Rotom, and Accelgor easily defeat Hattrem with their super effective STAB moves.

sets.name: Stall Support
sets.description:
Hattrem is the best user of Magic Bounce in ZU, carving it a niche as a unique form of entry hazard control. Psychic threatens most entry hazard setters, especially Qwilfish. Mystical Fire provides coverage for Alolan Sandslash while crippling special attackers that would switch into Hattrem, like Rotom, Thievul, and Skuntank. Rest is Hattrem's best form of recovery and lets it PP stall entry hazard setters it struggles to defeat with its offensive moves, like Galarian Stunfisk. Sleep Talk prevents Hattrem from being completely passive after using Rest. A physically defensive spread is preferred, as most entry hazard setters are physical attackers.

Hattrem fits best on defensive teams that heavily dislike entry hazards. Pokemon that are very susceptible to entry hazards like Alcremie, Cofagrigus, and Golbat enjoy Hattrem consistently keeping entry hazards off the field. A secondary remover such as Articuno, Altaria, or Cramorant is required to handle entry hazard setters like Accelgor and Rhydon, which can break through Hattrem. Solid physical and special walls such as Tangela, Pyukumuku and Stunfisk are needed, as Hattrem tends to invite in wallbreakers such as Silvally formes, Shiftry, and Rotom due to its average bulk and mediocre offensive presence.

Alcremie.comments:
Other Options

Alcremie can run a specially defensive set, making good use of its insane special bulk, access to Aromatherapy, and immunity to Taunt; however, this set is usually outclassed by Clefairy, which has Magic Guard and a superior support movepool. Draining Kiss, while far weaker than Dazzling Gleam, makes Alcremie less reliant on Recover. Flame Orb can be used to avoid Toxic without resorting to Rest or Aromatherapy, but the constant chip damage jeopardizes Alcremie's bulk and limits its setup opportunities.

Checks and Counters

Poison-types: Unless Alcremie is carrying a Psychic move, Poison-types like Poison Jab Qwilfish and Silvally-Poison can take on its attacks and retaliate back with their super effective STAB moves. However, passive ones like defensive Qwilfish lacking Poison Jab and Golbat lacking Toxic are usually unable to beat Alcremie, especially Double Dance sets. Skuntank is noteworthy, as its Psychic immunity allows it to handle every Alcremie variant.

Steel-types: Steel-types like Perrserker and Klinklang can take an unboosted Mystical Fire from Alcremie and OHKO back with their super effective STAB moves. They can even break through Acid Armor Alcremie by setting up.

Fire-types: Fire-types such as Ninetales and Rapidash resist Dazzling Gleam and Mystical Fire. They easily break through Alcremie with their STAB moves or use it as setup fodder.

Physical Wallbreakers: Even with maximum Defense investment, Alcremie is unable to take on powerful physical wallbreakers such as Silvally formes, Thwackey, and Cinccino. However, it can easily wall most of them after Acid Armor.

Dark-types: Even though Dark-types such as Silvally-Dark and Shiftry are obliterated by Dazzling Gleam, they completely wall Alcremie's Double Dance set thanks to their immunity to Stored Power. They can take advantage of it to set up.

sets.name: Defensive Calm Mind + Recover
sets.description:
Calm Mind Alcremie serves as a physical wall that is able to check foes like Sawk, Shiftry, and Gurdurr thanks to its typing while doubling as a threatening setup sweeper. Mystical Fire threatens Steel-types like Alolan Sandslash and Perrserker, which take little damage from Dazzling Gleam, while also heavily damaging Frosmoth. Alternatively, Aromatherapy allows Alcremie to sponge status and break through walls like Toxic Clefairy while also supporting partners that dislike getting statused, such as Miltank, Tangela, and Coalossal. However, without Mystical Fire, Alcremie is unable to beat Steel-types. Aroma Veil provides a Taunt immunity, allowing Alcremie to set up against foes such as Golbat and Qwilfish lacking Poison Jab. Sweet Veil is an option, giving Alcremie an immunity to sleep-inducing moves used by Tangela, Eldegoss, and Jynx.

Alcremie fits well on balance and bulky offense teams that appreciate its sweeping potential and defensive utility as a Fairy-type. Ground-types like Piloswine, Rhydon, and Stunfisk threaten Poison-types such as Silvally-Poison and Skutank. Partners such as Cramorant and Altaria deal with Fire-types such as Rapidash and Ninetales, which can break through Alcremie. Teammates such as Rapidash, Qwilfish, and Manectric, which can check Steel-types, also make for great partners. Strong special wallbreakers such as Basculin, Thievul, and Frosmoth can heavily weaken special walls, putting them in range of Alcremie's attacks. This can be very important if Alcremie is not running Aromatherapy to disregard Toxic from threats such as Clefairy and Wishiwashi.

sets.name: Double Dance
sets.description:
Double Dance Alcremie is great against stall and balance teams and has the potential to muscle through most teams once Dark-types have been removed. The combination of Calm Mind and Acid Armor bolsters Alcremie's bulk and Stored Power's base power to incredible levels. Stored Power is preferred for its ability to bypass Unaware Pyukumuku. Rest is used over Recover in order to play around Toxic and other status moves. Leftovers provides passive recovery, which is extremely valuable when Alcremie is asleep for two turns. However, Chesto Berry is an alternative that lets Alcremie fully heal once without drawback.

Because of Alcremie's inability to hit Dark-types, this set appreciates teammates weakening them. Attackers such as Thievul, Gourgeist-Small, and Shiftry can weaken Dark-types, especially with entry hazard support from setters such as Alolan Snowslash, Piloswine, and Uxie. Toxic Spikes from Runerigus and Qwilfish put Dark-types on a timer, although Skuntank is immune to them and some Dark-types like Morpeko run Heavy-Duty Boots. Fighting-types such as Gurdurr, Poliwrath, and Sawk check Dark- and Steel-types for Alcremie. Leftovers variants of Alcremie value having a sturdy defensive core to counteract its passivity and benefits from partners like Tangela and Altaria. Offensive Steel-types, mainly Perrserker and Klinklang, need to removed before Alcremie can sweep; therefore, teammates such as Rapidash and Sawk are appreciated.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
Offensive Alcremie is the best choice for an offensive Fairy-type. Mystical Fire nails Steel-types like Alolan Sandslash, Perrserker, and Klinklang and 2HKOes Frosmoth. Psychic destroys Poison-types like Silvally-Poison, Qwilfish, and Golbat, while Calm Mind lets Alcremie break through special walls like Articuno and Clefairy. Heavy-Duty Boots makes it easier for Alcremie to utilize its great defensive typing and switch in against foes like Thievul, Sawk, and Gurdurr, while Life Orb makes Alcremie a better wallbreaker.

Dark-types such as Shiftry, Silvally-Dark, and Morpeko enjoy Alcremie's ability to take on Fighting- and Dark-types such as Gurdurr and Alolan Persian. Physical wallbreakers such as Cinccino and Choice Band Basculin can force in physical walls and pivot, providing Alcremie with wallbreaking opportunities, while also threatening special walls such as Clefairy, which can handle Alcremie. Ground-types such as Rhydon, Stunfisk, and Piloswine check Fire- and Poison-types such as Rapidash and Silvally-Poison. Partners such as Qwilfish, Rapidash, and Appletun can also wall problematic Fire-types for Alcremie.

Frosmoth.comments:
Other Options

Bug Buzz can be used as a secondary STAB move to better damage foes like Uxie, but it is usually not needed; Frosmoth's other coverage moves are better, and having both STAB attacks is less effective due to overlapping resistances. Weather Ball is a good option on weather teams, giving Frosmoth coverage it usually doesn't have access to.

Checks and Counters

Fire-types: Fire-types like Ninetales and Rapidash are the best offensive answer against Frosmoth, easily OHKOing it due to its 4x weakness. Frosmoth will also have to watch out for Pokemon with Fire-type coverage such as Fire Blast Skuntank and Mystical Fire Alcremie.

Steel-types: Steel-types like Perrserker, Klinklang, and Alolan Sandslash can take on most of Frosmoth's attacks and threaten it back with their Steel-type moves.

Knock Off: Removing Frosmoth's Heavy-Duty Boots will heavily hinder its ability to sweep, as it will be susceptible to all type of entry hazards, especially Stealth Rock. Passive Pokemon like Clefairy and Tangela may bait in Frosmoth and remove its item.

Revenge Killers: Frosmoth's mediocre Speed and lackluster physical bulk make it easy to revenge kill, even at +1, by Choice Scarf users such as Sawk and Cinccino; the latter is also able to revenge kill Frosmoth behind a Substitute. Priority users like Kangaskhan, Shiftry, and Aqua Jet Basculin are able to revenge kill Frosmoth with minimal chip damage, although none of them can switch into Frosmoth's attacks with ease.

sets.name: Quiver Dance
sets.description:
Frosmoth is a great setup sweeper and offensive presence in the metagame thanks to its strong Special Attack, decent coverage, and access to Quiver Dance. Giga Drain threatens Water-types like Poliwrath and Wishiwashi, doing significant damage after a single boost. Substitute allows Frosmoth to set up on passive Pokemon that relies on status it to wear it down like Clefairy, Uxie, and Pyukumuku. Substitute also makes Frosmoth an excellent stallbreaker. Hurricane is an alternative to deal great damage to Fire-types such as Ninetales and Rapidash. However, without Substitute, Frosmoth has significantly less opportunities to set up and is easier to revenge kill.

Frosmoth fits on balance and bulky offense teams that want a setup sweeper and soft check to special attackers such as Rotom. Switch-ins to Fire-types are great partners; Pokemon like Qwilfish and Thick Fat Appletun can switch into Ninetales and Rapidash, respectively. Fighting-types like Gurdurr and Poliwrath can switch into Rock- and Steel-types like Rhydon and Alolan Sandslash, while Frosmoth in return can set up on foes like Uxie and Tangela that switch into them. Secondary sweepers like Iron Defense Cofagrigus and Silvally formes can pressure foes and weaken them for Frosmoth to sweep late-game; they also pressure Frosmoth's checks such as Choice Scarf Sawk and Galarian Stunfisk. Qwilfish can absorb and scout for Knock Off users while setting entry hazards for Frosmoth to sweep.
